Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Oregon Spotted Frogs It is unacceptable that the Forest Service permits grazing in Oregon spotted frog (OSF) habitat that leads to the extirpation of the Jack Creek OSF population. Once again, it does not appear that US Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) provided any input to this project. It’s not reasonable to assume FWS would authorize “take” for the specific grazing actions this DEIS proposes, especially since many other OSF populations in the Klamath Basin are also being affected by grazing and proposed grazing actions can be mitigated.  The Forest Wildlife Biologist has been in contact with the US Fish and Wildlife Service during the analysis for this project; and meetings, both in the field and office, were held. Additionally, the biologist references documents reviewed or compiled in part by the FWS: “A Conservation Assessment for the Oregon Spotted Frog (Rana pretiosa), which is incorporated by reference, includes a detailed account of the life history, threats, and management considerations for OSFs (Cushman  JG-04  and Pearl 2007). The Conservation Agreement for the Oregon Spotted Frog (Rana pretiosa) in the Klamath Basin of Oregon, was completed in May of 2010 in partnership between the Fremont-Winema National Forest, Klamath Fall Fish and Wildlife Service, Klamath Marsh National Wildlife Refuge, Lakeview District of the Bureau of Land Management and Medford District of the Bureau of Land Management.” (Antelope Grazing Allotments Project, Chapter 3 Wildlife Resources, Revised October 16, 2014) The Forest is currently in consultation with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The DEIS states, “The Forest Service is in consultation with the USFWS for development of a Biological Assessment and expects a letter of concurrence on this action” (section 1.8.6, p. 1-12).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-05  The DEIS OSF analysis shows livestock grazing poses many threats to OSF and that alternatives 3 and 5 actually increase negative effects, yet it fails to propose effective conservation measures that will mitigate those negative effects. Rather, the DEIS proposes to increase the number, extent and duration of negative grazing effects in OSF habitat along Jack Creek that leads to extirpation.  The DEIS acknowledges that grazing may reduce (i.e., an indicator changed to a worse rating compared to the environmental baseline) some of the threats to Oregon spotted frog. However, a biological assessment determined that the proposed action “may impact individuals or habitat, but will not likely contribute to a trend towards federal listing or cause a loss of viability to the population or species.”  JG-06  This proposed action relies on other OSF populations in the Klamath Basin to maintain species viability. This reliance is unacceptable because the Jack Creek population gene pool is critical to maintaining species diversity across the frog’s range.  JG-07  This DEIS does not disclose a Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) biological opinion. Neither the DEIS nor FOIA records indicate the Antelope Grazing Project IDT considered or incorporated any FWS input. The Winema Forest Plan (FP) requires that species viability be maintained and the Endangered Species Act requires the Forest to consult on actions affecting OSF. This DEIS must have a major overhaul of both grazing actions proposed and conservation measures needed to meet either of the above requirements.  Please see comment JG-04.  JG-08  The DEIS premise that grazing will improve OSF breeding habitat in Jack Creek is unsupported. Stated benefits are baseless because there is no reed canarygrass in breeding habitat.  Comment noted. The Wildlife Specialist Report identifies several threats to the OSF, grazing being one of them (Wildlife Report, pp. 44–49). The Matrix of Threats and Potential Impacts (pp. 60–62) displays the effects of livestock grazing on the OSF, both beneficial and negative.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS and Wildlife Specialist Report mistakenly assert that livestock grazing could have some positive impacts to breeding habitat for the Jack Creek population due to reduction in vegetation, and that lack of grazing could have negative impacts to breeding habitat that lead to a reduction in breeding success. The Threatened Listing Rule for Oregon Spotted frogs (79FR51672) states “Studies conducted in Washington (White 2002, pp. 45–46; Pearl and Hayes 2004, pp. 22–23) demonstrated that the quality of breeding habitats for Oregon spotted frogs is improved by reducing the height of the previous year’s emergent vegetation (i.e., reed canarygrass in these cases [emphasis added]).” Further discussion of this issue in the Threatened Listing Rule indicates that benefits from grazing are limited to sites where reed canarygrass has become dominant in breeding areas. Reed canary grass does not occur at Jack Creek oviposition sites and the extent it occurs elsewhere is very confined to less than a tenth acre that is already being treated. Thus the findings cited do not apply and are taken out of context in this DEIS.  The Threatened Listing Rule for Oregon spotted frogs (79FR51672) states, “For example, in all occupied sub-basins in Washington and in the Klamath sub-basin in Oregon, an indirect effect of the removal of cattle grazing has been the reduction in the amount and quality of breeding and rearing habitat due to encroachment by vegetation, such as reed canarygrass and shrubs. The effects of grazing vary among sites and likely depend on a suite of factors including, but not limited to, timing, intensity, duration, and how these factors interact with seasonal habitat use patterns of Oregon spotted frog.”  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Furthermore, it is now believed winter snowpack provides  Comment noted.  JG-09  compression of grasses and livestock grazing is unnecessary where snowpack occurs. This assertion is supported in the final listing rule. The Threatened Listing Rule for Oregon Spotted frogs (79FR51676) states: “Cattle grazing ceased at Trout Lake NAP in Washington after a monitoring study showed no apparent positive effect on the Oregon spotted frog population trends (Wilderman and Hallock 2004, p. 10), indicating that either grazing was not an effective tool for reed canarygrass management at this location, or that perhaps reed canarygrass was not as threatening to breeding frogs at this location as previously thought. This may be because winter snow pack compresses the reed canarygrass, leaving none of the previous season’s vertical stems available to Oregon spotted frogs during the breeding season. The observed negative consequences of grazing, while perhaps acceptable if there was clear benefit to the Oregon spotted frog populations, were not compatible with other site management goals and posed a limitation to future restoration on the site [emphasis added] (Wilderman and Hallock 2004, p.14).” Snowpack compression of vegetation is certainly the case in Jack Creek where the vast majority of annual precipitation comes in the form of snow.  Section 3.10.1.1 (p. 3-177) of the DEIS states, “Available data for temperature and precipitation trends between 2000 and 2010 for locations within these basins show overall decreases in mean temperature and increases in precipitation (Table 332) (OWSC 2011).” Section 3.10.2.1 (p. 3-179) of the DEIS continues, “As future average temperatures increase, snowpack will very likely be reduced, and snowmelt, runoff, and peak flows will occur earlier in the year (Hauser et al. 2009).” “Spotted frogs use sites with early seral vegetation (Hayes 1998). Historically, disturbance regimes that favored maintenance of open water and early seral-stage vegetation structure included fire and the activities of beaver. Cattle grazing may have helped maintain suitable vegetative structure in the absence of beaver and fire (Hayes 1998).” Jack Creek Oregon Spotted Frog (Rana pretiosa) Site Management Plan (11/28/2011).  Livestock grazing to remove biomass in breeding habitat at Jack Creek is unwarranted because as stated above there is no reed canarygrass in breeding habitat and winter snow pack compresses the grass biomass making grass removal by livestock unnecessary.  “There is one known site of Canada thistle and reed canary grass. These sights are small and do not appear to be expanding. These sites were treated with herbicide in 2012 and 2013.” (Wildlife Report, p. 62)  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-12  The DEIS fails to identify existing or desired site specific breeding habitat conditions at known oviposition sites. Therefore, there is no basis to claim a need to improve them using grazing or any other action that removes vegetation. This analysis must be done and must include private lands that are being issued term private land grazing permits.  Desired conditions in an EIS are determined by desired conditions in the appropriate Forest Plan, regulations, laws, and other direction. Desired conditions for the OSF are noted on page 49 of the Wildlife Report, which is a reference to the OSF Site Management Plan.  JG-13  A review of the FOIA records shows that Area Ecologist Gregg Riegel made several comments to the Jack Creek Oregon Spotted Frog Site Management Plan (SMP). He pointed out that there is a big difference between managing for early seral structure versus early seral plant communities in breeding habitat. He goes on to say that the SMP does not distinguish which is being referenced. He commented that because existing and desired site specific vegetation structure, seral stage and species composition for breeding habitat are not defined, there was no basis for determining a need to manipulate breeding habitat using grazing or any other action. Neither the SMP nor the DEIS are responsive to the Area Ecologist’s comments.  The analysis being completed is for the Antelope grazing allotment project and not for the Oregon Spotted Frog management plan (i.e., Jack Creek Site Management Plan). The Jack Creek Site Management Plan is not a decision document. This commenter had opportunity to provide comment during the development of the Jack Creek Site Management Plan, these comments were considered at that time.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-14  Recognition of the site specific differences in vegetation within breeding habitat is necessary in order to determine whether suitable conditions exist or changes are needed to improve breeding habitat. The DEIS fails to do this. Terry Simpson, the Chemult District biologist (now retired) who conducted many years of egg mass surveys along Jack Creek, has seen a variety of springtime breeding conditions at each breeding location. For instance, she has observed that the vegetation species composition, height, and density of the bluegrass dominated meadow in JCP 4 (lower Jamison) breeding habitat were very different from the willow/sedge breeding habitat in JCP 2 (lower Jack). She also noted that breeding occurred early enough in spring that there was often no new plant growth, or at best very little. As a result, vegetation present at oviposition sites consisted of remnants of the previous year’s growth, not new season early seral growth.  Comment noted. Page 27 of the Jack Creek Oregon Spotted Frog Site Management Plan states, “Desired site conditions are a vibrant, fully functioning riparian system with increasing R. pretiosa populations that expand first into formerly occupied habitat and later into areas currently identified as potential habitat. Restored hydrological conditions include sunny, unshaded open water for breeding and rearing, with plentiful off-channel shallows. Deep water and springs for overwintering would also help maintain summer water. Desired site conditions also include maintenance of appropriate vegetation structure in breeding pools and summer areas, and a restored water table. Other desired conditions are off-channel frog habitat in the form of ponds and springs that maintain water throughout the active season, and pools and channels within the creek that are sufficiently deep to provide over-winter habitat.”  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-15  The lower Jamison (JCP 4) bluegrass breeding habitat is a nonnative, early seral community in less than good condition (Simpson professional opinion based on several years of egg mass surveys prior to 2008 and observations over the fence after 2008). Bluegrass is subordinate to forbs like yarrow, dandelion, pussytoes, strawberry and aster. Openings in the litter layer are common (Kovalchik 1988). Most vegetation is less than a foot in height at its peak growth and is flattened to within a couple inches of the ground under snowpack. So a water column at the JCP 4 oviposition site is absent of vegetation at all but the very lower end of water column depth. Egg masses laid in low water depths below 10 cm are most prone to stranding. Removing vegetation to create access into shallow water below 10 cm should not be encouraged. Given its low vegetation stature, open grown characteristics and tendency to flatten to the ground under snowpack, bluegrass oviposition sites are within the low vegetation density category without livestock grazing. Any further vegetation removal only degrades breeding habitat.  Comment noted. Alternatives 3 and 5 would allow for grazing of private lands, including Upper Jamison and Lower Jamison, under a term private grazing permit (FEIS, pp. 2-12 through 2-15 and 2-23 through 2-27). These areas would be under the same monitoring requirements as in Appendix D of the FEIS and administration adjustments as presented in the Adaptive Management Strategy (Appendix D).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-16  In contrast, the willow/sedge breeding habitat in the lower Jack reach (JCP 2) is a native, late seral wetland community dominated by a mix of sedges (Simpson opinion based on annual field observations since 1999). Riparian shrubs are common. Sedges can exceed heights of 24” at their peak growth. Sedges also flatten under snowpack. During the breeding season most of the sedge vegetation lays as a moderate to somewhat dense floating mat within and on top of the water column unless water levels are very low (<10 cm). Vertical and horizontal gaps in the vegetation mat exist, permitting OSF movement and egg laying. Usually those gaps do not exist in low water breeding conditions, so OSF are very unlikely to use breeding habitat with less than 10 cm water depth. In comparison to bluegrass sites, the denser vegetation mat moves OSF into water deeper than 10 cm where stranding is less likely to occur. The vegetation mat through much of the water column at oviposition sites also provides excellent hiding/forage cover for breeding adults and emerging tadpoles. These are characteristics to be managed for and grazing only degrades them.  Comment noted. Alternatives 3 and 5 would allow for grazing of private lands, including Upper Jamison and Lower Jamison, under a term private grazing permit (FEIS, pp. 2-12 through 2-15 and 2-23 through 2-27). These areas would be under the same monitoring requirements as in Appendix D of the FEIS and administration adjustments as presented in the Adaptive Management Strategy (Appendix D).  JG-17  Reed canarygrass provides very dense vegetation that can plug up breeding sites where OSF lay eggs. Reed canarygrass is much taller, and grows in much denser colonies than existing vegetation at Jack Creek oviposition sites. If present, reed canarygrass would likely degrade or destroy breeding sites in Jack Creek. All precautions should be taken to insure that reed canarygrass is not spread in Jack Creek. Since cattle grazing creates both the medium for new establishment and the means to spread seeds, grazing should not be allowed in breeding habitat on Jack Creek to prevent the spread of reed canarygrass.  The risk of invasive plant, including reed cannarygrass, introduction and spread is detailed in the section 3.2 (“Botanical Resources and Invasive Plants”) of the DEIS (p. 3-19).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Analysis of existing conditions in Jack Creek breeding habitat to  The biological opinion, completed February 12,  determine what, if any, grazing level is appropriate has not been  2015, identifies current conditions for the project  JG-18  done. The DEIS and OSF biological assessment must be redone to define existing and desired site specific breeding habitat characteristics, and then to describe site specific conservation measures to preserve or improve proper conditions.  area (pp. 26–41).  JG-19  As proposed in the DEIS, grazing in breeding habitat in less than good condition and with inherent low density vegetation degrades breeding habitat, increases OSF mortality due to predation and increases the potential for stranding. Conservation measures need to be identified that recover degraded breeding habitat conditions, not perpetuate or further degrade them.  A monitoring plan would accompany the implementation of any alternatives. This plan would consist of monitoring the different resources associated with the allotment and Oregon spotted frog, including but not limited to, hydrologic, range, and wildlife resources. Monitoring would be intended to evaluate progress toward the management goals, detect changes in the resources, and determine trends in resource condition. The data collected would provide a basis for implementing adaptive management in order to meet the management objectives associated with this permitted action.  JG-20  A review of FOIA records indicates that Chris Pearl made comments to the SMP about breeding habitat conditions. He commented that moderate to somewhat dense vegetation for Jack Creek is preferred and that too little or too high density should be avoided. The DEIS and wildlife report ignore these comments made by a well published OSF researcher well acquainted with Jack Creek.  Chris Pearl’s work is referenced numerous times throughout the FEIS and individual reports (FEIS, p. R-10). Pearl is referenced in the Wildlife Report at least 24 times, including use of his co-authored work: A Conservation Assessment for the Oregon Spotted Frog (Rana pretiosa) (Cushman & Pearl, March 2007).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  An understanding of the grazing history of lower Jamison meadow is important in order to understand vegetation conditions in breeding habitat. Until 2008, both ownerships in lower Jamison were grazed together under private management. There was a two-year period of no grazing. In 2010 grazing resumed under private management on a portion of lower Jamison. This new grazing area is referenced as JCP 4 in this DEIS. Fences were ineffective in keeping cattle off the lower portion of the meadow unauthorized for grazing and letters of noncompliance were issued in 2011 and 2013 (see attachments).  This comment is noted. Grazing within Oregon spotted frog habitat will be evaluated by annual implementation and effectiveness monitoring as described in Appendix D. Standards and guidelines are applied over a landscape activity area. The random nature of cattle movement makes knowing where damage will occur outside of favorite hangout areas difficult.  JG-21  In the 2011 noncompliance letter, range specialists said that utilization was 24% from unauthorized grazing in lower Jamison Meadow below the property line fence. This measurement, in combination with photos taken by Jayne Goodwin, provides further clarification of the breeding habitat issue. Please see the two photos below. The first photo was taken in October 2011 where the 24% utilization was measured. The cow pies are taller than the vegetation. As a result, there was virtually no vegetation present in breeding habitat for the 2012 breeding season. The second photo was taken in October 2013 at the property line fence. That portion grazed under private management (and soon to become JCP 4) is the top of the photo above the fence and that portion of lower Jamison unauthorized for grazing below the fence. No utilization measures were provided in the 2013 letter. The second photo shows that like 2011 there is very little vegetation present in October 2013 and vegetation density would be very light at breeding sites in 2014. Twenty-four percent utilization is well below the 35% proposed in the DEIS for both sides of the fence in this meadow. Grazing to improve breeding habitat conditions in the lower Jamison Meadow cannot be justified.  Evidence of damage at one site in a pasture does not necessarily mean damage occurs there every year. Favorite locations for cattle to hang out have been identified and measures have been incorporated into the grazing system to improve dispersal, or the areas have been excluded from grazing to protect individual resources of concern. The Adaptive Management Strategy and the Monitoring Requirements (Appendix D) will help identify any items outside thresholds and implement mitigation measures.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  24% utilization in 2011 in lower Jamison  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Utilization at the lower Jamison property line in 2013  JG-23  The DEIS currently states that conditions are unknown on the private and a general EUI habitat description will be used. This is unacceptable. Since management of the private parcel on lower Jamison is proposed to be waived to the federal government and the Forest intends to issue a term private grazing permit, this DEIS must include detailed existing and desired conditions for private lands under permit as well.  The term/private permits provides the mechanism to control grazing on private lands such that impacts in spotted frog habitat can be reduced. It is a cooperative agreement between the land owner and the Forest that would allow use of available forage in a way that provides better protection of spotted frog habitat.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Forest Service Desired Conditions for Riparian areas can only be applied to National Forest System Lands, the terms, and conditions of a term private land grazing permit are only to implement grazing standards for livestock use on private lands.  JG-24  The bluegrass breeding habitat in Lower Jamison (JCP 4) is already at the “too light” vegetative density condition and any grazing is likely to move it even further away from desired conditions. Conservation measures are needed to restore acceptable breeding habitat conditions in lower Jamison meadow. These measures should include complete rest from grazing to improve vegetation vigor and species composition. Headcuts and incised channel conditions in lower Jamison need repairs to restore water tables levels that will improve vigor and support native plant communities in breeding habitat.  Comment noted. Grazing within Oregon spotted frog habitat will be reviewed by annual implementation and effectiveness monitoring as described in Appendix D.  JG-25  Livestock grazing is clearly detrimental to breeding habitat in lower Jamison. Conservation measures are needed to recover breeding habitat damaged from past grazing. A 35% utilization standard may also move other sites that are currently in desirable condition into unacceptable “too light” vegetation density conditions. Analysis of existing conditions in Jack Creek breeding habitat to determine what, if any, grazing level is appropriate has not been done. The DEIS and OSF biological assessment must be redone to define existing and desired site specific breeding habitat characteristics and to describe site specific conservation measures to preserve or improve proper conditions. Private lands to be permitted under term private land permits must be included in this analysis.  Comment noted. Grazing within Oregon spotted frog habitat will be reviewed by annual implementation and effectiveness monitoring as described in Appendix D. Effects of grazing on Oregon spotted frog habitat are discussed in the DEIS on section 3.3.1 (pp. 3-68 through 3-80).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-26  The DEIS proposes to use grazing as a conservation measure to improve OSF breeding habitat, but then extends grazing to all critical habitat. The number, extent and duration of negative effects from grazing to other primary constituent elements of proposed critical habitat will jeopardize OSF and degrade or destroy proposed critical habitat in Jack Creek. This DEIS does not propose any mitigation measures to protect against future harm or restore past damage.  The Forest is currently in consultation with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will determine jeopardy to the Oregon spotted frog. Effects of grazing on Oregon spotted frog are discussed in the DEIS on section 3.3.1 (pp. 3-68 through 3-80.  As commented above, it is highly questionable that grazing will improve breeding habitat conditions in Jack Creek. It is incomprehensible why a questionable practice would then be applied to all other habitat components given all the grazing threats this DEIS identifies. In order to recover this population, habitat conservation measures must be identified that not only protect against future harm but also repair past grazing damage. This DEIS fails to identify those  Page 2-35 of the DEIS lists the wildlife design features specific to Oregon spotted frog: • WI(3,5)-1—Install an off-channel water source within the Lower Jack Creek Pasture before grazing commences in the Jack Creek Unit  JG-27  measures. Future grazing must not be considered until all past grazing damage is restored and a healthy, stable frog population is reestablished in Jack Creek.  • WI(3,5)-2—Ensure the utilization levels average 35% within all areas identified as Oregon spotted frog habitat • WI(3,5)-3—Grazing within the Jack Creek Unit would vary in years prior to completion of Oregon spotted frog restoration actions, and appropriate grazing levels would be identified each grazing season through preseason monitoring (Appendix D). • WI(3,5)-4—Discourage late-season grazing in occupied Oregon spotted frog habitat to protect metamorphosing spotted frogs In addition, Appendix D provides the monitoring plan and the adaptive management strategy.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-28  The Jack Creek channel provides critical open water, overwinter and low water refugia habitat for OSF, yet the DEIS and specialist reports provide vague, confusing and incomplete descriptions of existing and desired future conditions that provide the basis for analysis and conservation measures needed. As a result, the analysis of grazing impacts on OSF is misleading and insufficient.  Section 3.7.1.2.2 discloses the scientific uncertainty related to grazing within Oregon spotted frog habitat. The potential positive or negative effects of grazing to Oregon spotted frog have been analyzed in the EIS, section 3.3.1. Page 3-71 of the DEIS describes the desired conditions for Oregon spotted frog habitat in Jack Creek as follows: “Desired conditions for Jack Creek include restored hydrological conditions with unshaded open water for breeding and rearing and plentiful off-channel shallows. Deep water and springs for overwintering would also help maintain summer water. Desired site conditions also include maintenance of appropriate vegetation structure in breeding pools and summer areas, and a restored water table. Other desired conditions include off-channel habitat in the form of ponds and springs that maintain water throughout the active season, and pools and channels within the creek that are sufficiently deep to provide overwinter habitat.” See the response to comment JG-19 for details about the monitoring plan and response to comment JG-13 for the desired conditions provided in the Jack Creek Oregon Spotted Frog Site Management Plan.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-29  A Level II stream survey appears to be the basis for describing existing channel conditions. A review of where the level II survey was performed indicates that only portions of the perennial reach from the 8821 Road crossing upstream to the 94 Road was done. The three miles of Jack Creek on private property and the several miles of intermittent creek from the 8821 Road crossing down through proposed critical habitat in O’Connor Meadow were not surveyed. Only four of the seven miles of perennial creek and about one-half mile of the eight miles of intermittent creek were surveyed. In other words, there is no channel survey information available on about 10.5 miles of the 15 miles of Jack Creek that provide OSF critical habitat. Further review shows that no bank assessment was performed anywhere. Without comprehensive stream survey data, there is no basis to define threats (changes in channel morphology, disconnection from the floodplain, headcuts, and loss of overhanging banks) and existing conditions for channel critical habitat elements.  The level II stream surveys are not conducted on private lands without permission of landowner. Only the lengths of dry main channels, such as within North Sheep pasture, are measured. See DEIS for discussions on bank stability (pp. 3-75 through 3-87; 3-130; 3-134 through 3-136) and channel conditions (pp. 3-116 through 3-132).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-30  An assumption can be made that INFISH Riparian Management Objectives (RMOs) are the basis for describing desired future conditions for Jack Creek OSF channel critical habitat because no other detailed desired conditions are described in the DEIS or specialist reports. A review of RMOs (DEIS Table 3-21, pg. 3-131) indicates Jack creek does not meet pool frequency in reaches 6 (in JCP 2), 7 (in JCP 1) and 9 (in Chemult pasture), does not meet large woody debris in reaches 6, 7 and 9, does not meet the width-to-depth ratio in reach 6, and does not show if the creek meets the lower bank angle RMO anywhere because lower bank angle was not measured. The DEIS and specialist reports do not provide any information to determine whether RMO’s are being met for reaches 1-5 (8821 Road crossing up through upper Jamison meadow), reach 8 (Moffit private property) or the eight miles of intermittent creek in the proposed Sheep & Goat pasture. There is discussion that these RMOs are for perennial creeks and cool water fishes (not warm water OSF that are living in both perennial and intermittent sections of the creek) and that these RMOs are not a good fit for Jack Creek for a variety of reasons. As stated in INFISH (page E-3), “RMOs should be refined to better reflect conditions that are attainable in a specific watershed or stream reach.” Yet the DEIS does not define new RMOs that provide a better fit for OSF and Jack Creek. This RMO refinement must be done in order to complete an adequate analysis on stream channel critical habitat components and impacts to OSF. RMOs must be developed for more than just channel conditions and must also include the adjacent riparian zones that are also part of OSF critical habitat.  INFISH RMOs are described and effects to habitat conditions summarized on pp. 3-130 through 3-141 of the DEIS.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-31  The DEIS does not adequately identify or analyze channel conditions under the different alternatives to ensure that INFISH standards are met. INFISH "GM-1: Modify grazing practices (e.g. accessibility of riparian areas to livestock, length of grazing season, stocking levels, and timing of grazing) that retard or prevent attainment of Riparian Management Objectives or are likely to adversely affect inland native fish. Suspend grazing if adjusting practices are not effective in meeting Riparian Management Objectives."  Note the analysis done under Hydrology for Streamflow (p. 3-121) and the effects analysis for Fisheries that covers water quality; the specialists’ reports; and the adaptive management strategy, particularly the monitoring of riparian areas and streambank conditions.  JG-33  NEPA requires that each alternative be analyzed regarding RMO standards apprpriate to Jack Creek and this was not done. Since the "no grazing" alternative will clearly result in the most rapid recovery of channel characteristics, the grazing alternatives will therefore clearly retard attainment of RMOs in violation of INFISH.  INFISH RMOs are described and effects to habitat conditions summarized on pp 3-130 through 3-141 of the FEIS.  JG-34  Relying on upland water sources to mitigate grazing threats while still allowing cattle to graze and drink from OSF habitat is not acceptable. Cattle will continue to eat, drink, loaf and travel through OSF habitat without sufficient relief to mitigate OSF threats. The creek must be fenced to exclude cattle in addition to putting in upland water sources.  These effects are described in section 3.3.1.1.4 (p. 3-75) of the DEIS. Effects were found to be within existing Forest Plan standards and guidelines and would not cause a trend toward federal listing for Oregon spotted frog. Design features (p. 2-35) have been added to minimize effects to Oregon spotted frog. Monitoring and adaptive management (Appendix D) have also been included for the project.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-35  The new lower Jamison pasture (JCP 4) allows cattle access to all OSF habitat and provides an upland water source intended to reduce negative OSF-cattle impacts. Last summer Simpson installed motion detecting cameras on a small section of the creek to determine how cattle with access to an upland water source used a small OSF pool in Jack Creek. See attachment Lower Jamison Photo Monitoring 2014. Cameras were deployed from August 24 through August 31. Cattle were on the OSF creek site for at least one activity period for five of the seven days. Day #1 had two herds pass through, Day #2 one herd, Day #3 three herds, Day #5 one herd and Day #7 two herds. Numbers of cattle and duration of activities in OSF habitat varied from a couple cows for less than 15 minutes to a herd of at least 15 cattle for over an hour and a half. One deer was photographed walking along the creek bank by one of the cameras. Cattle were photographed trailing in the creek to and from the channel pool, climbing banks into and out of the creek, grazing along bank edges, and grazing and loafing in the nearby meadow. Trampling and hooves punching into the mud and destabilizing the banks and channel are clearly visible. Loss of vegetation from trampling and grazing are clearly visible. Degraded channel conditions are being perpetuated with each cow passing through. The photos show clearly that the cattle were doing everything in OSF habitat that they would do regardless of the upland water source with the same types of negative impacts to OSF and habitat.  Effects from trampling on streambanks have been disclosed under section 3.5 (pp. 3-121 through 3-124). As stated on page 3-128 (effects disclosure for Alternative 3), water quality downstream of the springs would improve because sediment inputs from cattle trampling would be reduced or eliminated due to the construction of protection fences around streams. Streambank conditions are also discussed in section 3.6 (Fisheries) on pp. 3-152, 3-153, 3-155). Section 3.3.1 (p. 3-74), discusses threats to Oregon spotted frog, including headcuts, loss of overhanging banks, water quality, and changes in channel morphology.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-37  An upland water source is not an effective OSF conservation measure when cattle are still allowed to eat, drink, and loaf in OSF habitat. It only becomes an effective conservation measure when cattle are fenced off the creek with the only water source being provided in the upland. Fencing the creek would be a very effective conservation measure that should be used on Jack Creek.  As noted in section 3.3.1.1.5 of the EIS, research indicates that high intensity/low frequency grazing systems can change the spatial distribution and cause animals to graze the landscape more uniformly by decreasing the time of exposure to grazing and trampling. This section continues that monitoring will be necessary for managing this allotment in conjunction with Oregon spotted frog habitat. Monitoring & Adaptive management strategy has been detailed in Appendix D.  JG-38  The claim the DEIS (page 1-8) makes that the stockings, timings, and utilizations of private inholdings would be at the private landowners’ choosing if not waived to Fre-Win management is misleading. The permittee’s family has been working with FWS to improve OSF habitat for several years now. Nexus has been established and the FWS is responsible to provide the necessary guidance (stockings, timings, and utilizations) in grazing management on private lands even if management is not waived to the Fre-Win.  The DEIS makes that statement to explain how this issue partially drove the development of Alternatives 3 and 5. As stated in section 1.7.2, Alternative 5 proposes to permit grazing within the Oregon spotted frog habitat within Jack Creek under a term private land grazing permit to allow the Forest to manage grazing within critical habitat. Alternative 3 proposes to incorporate grazing on private lands within Jack Creek by designating a separate grazing unit within the Chemult Pasture instead of using a stand-alone pasture. Cooperative grazing of private lands allows for Forest Service standards to be implemented along with USFWS requirements for Oregon spotted frog protection.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-39  The Permittee’s family has been working with FWS and Klamath Secured Rural Schools Resource Advisory Committee (RAC) for several years now. They have accepted federal dollars to install upland water sources and wattles, put up pasture boundary fences and cut down encroachment to improve OSF habitat on their private lands with OSF habitat. The FWS is required to work with them to recover this population and restore degraded habitat as long as that nexus exists. The FWS and Fre-Win can coordinate recovery efforts across ownerships in Jack Creek regardless which agency manages the grazing on private lands.  As stated in section 2.3.5.1 of the DEIS, grazing within Jack Creek would be variable during the lifetime of this analysis because ongoing Oregon spotted frog habitat restoration would be occurring and would influence the locations, stockings, timings, and utilizations of grazing each year (see “Wildlife” section, Chapter 3). In addition, annual monitoring as outlined in Appendix D may influence the locations, stockings, timings, and utilizations of grazing each year. According to the ESA, critical habitat designations affect only federal agency actions or federally funded or permitted activities. Waiving grazing management to the Forest Service will provide closer monitoring of critical habitat and incorporation of Forest Service standards and guidelines.  JG-40  The FWS has the responsibility and authority to provide necessary conservation measures and coordination across ownerships in Jack Creek regardless of whether management of private lands is waived to the Fre-Win. The public has a reasonable expectation that FWS ESA authority across all ownerships will be sufficient to help the recovery of the Jack Creek OSF population.  The USFWS is responsible for administering the ESA. A term private grazing permit allows grazing management on private lands to follow Forest Service standards.  Groundwater Dependent Ecosystems Page 5 of the hydrology specialist report confirms that assessments of over 60 fens and springs A review of FOIA records indicate that fen assessments were not throughout the project area were made during the done following methods described in the DEIS, and many were done 2010 and 2011 field seasons, following the without an interdisciplinary team. The IDT soil scientist was not present at four of those transects. Neither the soils specialist report nor the DEIS describe methods used to collect this data or justification to extrapolate this data to other fens or riparian areas. These works are carried into the FEIS, Chapter 3 under the Botanical and Hydrology sections.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-47  For several years, Dr. Michael Cummings, Portland State University hydrogeologist, has been studying the hydrologic systems supporting the peatlands that provide habitat for numerous sensitive species in the Chemult Pasture. See attached entire Cummings Declaration; Cummings July 6, 2014 Report (new information); and Cummings et al Hydrogeology of Pumice-Hosted Fens 2014. Dr. Rick Dewey, the Regional bryophyte specialist, has also been monitoring these peatlands. See Simpson declaration exhibit 6, Dewey monitoring well data. Both Dr. Cummings and Dr. Dewey have considerable expertise and multiple years of site specific data on physical and biotic features in these unique peatland habitats that are not being considered in this DEIS. Their expertise and data should be used to better define  The botanist cites the work of Rick Dewey several times in the Biological Evaluation and Specialist Report for Botanical Species, Terrestrial Mollusks, and Three Terrestrial Insects Antelope Grazing Project (07/2013). Cummings was contacted and information used in this same Specialist Report. The work of Michael Cummings is used in the Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Hydrology Specialist Report (07/2013). These works are carried into the FEIS, Chapter 3 under the Botanical and Hydrology sections.  ecosystem form and function, specific water chemistry variables and trend information on site specific water table levels throughout the GDE complex (all critical sensitive species habitat values not fully analysed in this DEIS). By failing to incorporate or analyze information about changing water tables, individualized GDE responses to drought conditions, and differing GDE habitat characteristics that support a variety of rare plants, the DEIS and supporting specialist reports/BEs failed to take a hard look at the impacts of authorizing livestock grazing on the GDE habitats.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-48  Specifically, Dr. Dewey’s well monitoring data shows that water table levels vary tremendously from year to year in GDEs all over the project area which can add further stress to groundwater dependent sensitive species already impacted by livestock grazing in these habitats. According to his data, the vast majority of GDEs monitored have experienced lowered water tables below the 15-20 centimeter (cm) threshold for peat development over a four-year monitoring period, with 48% experiencing lowered water tables in 2013. Water levels are lowest in the summer months, especially August and September, when cattle are present on the allotment and are already actively impacting GDE vegetation. See Simpson Declaration paragraphs 54-59.  As stated on page 3-116 of the DEIS, “’Excessive’ fluctuations in the groundwater table are site specific. Groundwater dynamics were monitored at many locations throughout the project area (Aldous and Gurrieri 2012) and were used for calibration of what constituted ‘excessive’ fluctuations in the water table at springs and fens within the project area.”  JG-49  Dr. Cummings presents information confirming that water tables were lowered in 2013 and were still lower in 2014 in response to drought conditions. See Cummings July 6, 2014 Report summary on page 9. These levels were especially low when compared to higher levels measured in 2011 and 2012. Water tables were expected to drop further as the summer progressed. Water table measurements taken at piezometers along the 94 Rd and 94-350 Rd in January 2015 indicate water table in this area is still lower than that measured since midyear 2013 (Simpson personal communication with Dr. Cummings). Low water tables have the effect of further stressing the peatland-dependent species and exacerbating the impacts of cattle  The botanist cites the work of Rick Dewey several times in the Biological Evaluation and Specialist Report for Botanical Species, Terrestrial Mollusks, and Three Terrestrial Insects Antelope Grazing Project (07/2013). Cummings was contacted and information used in this same Specialist Report. The work of Michael Cummings is used in the Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Hydrology Specialist Report (07/2013).  grazing and trampling on peatland surfaces. Dr. Cummings’ data also shows that the GDEs within the Chemult District exhibit differing responses to drought conditions (again see Cummings July 6, 2014 Report pages 8-9). These individualized responses and tolerances for drought within each GDE habitat must be taken into account in the DEIS analysis of impacts to GDEs from proposed grazing.  These works are carried into the FEIS, Chapter 3 under the Botanical and Hydrology sections.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-50  The DEIS and specialist reports take an arbitrary approach to analysing some of the GDEs’ physical and biotic characteristics rather than using methodical or site specific methods, thus failing to take a hard look at the potential direct, indirect, and cumulative impacts to GDEs and dependent species from livestock grazing. Simpson declaration at paragraph 66 says BEs and specialist reports that assess conditions of and impacts to sensitive species’ habitat must identify and describe the physical and biotic characteristics of that habitat in order to analyze impacts to the host of rare species they support. Under multiple well-established assessment protocols, the GDE/fen habitat characteristics that must be described and analyzed include: location, size, hydrogeomorphic setting, broadscale and community level floristic composition, water chemistry (including temperature, pH, specific conductance), disturbance (to vegetation, soil, hydrology and watershed), and the magnitude of disturbance on quantity and function for each fen/wetland. The physical and biotic conditions present define the potential each GDE/fen has to support specific communities and species. Gen. Tech. Report WO-86b is the nationally approved protocol to do a project level inventory of groundwater-dependent ecosystems (GDE) including fens. The nationally approved protocol was not used.  The current conditions of groundwater-dependent ecosystems in the project area are discussed in section 3.5.1.1 of the DEIS.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-51  Proposed Directives for Managing Groundwater, published at 79 FR 25815 to 25824 in the Federal Register May 6, 2014, incorporate the best available science on the matter of managing GDEs. Much of the data and discussions that went into the foundation documents for these proposed directives (2007 Technical Guide to Managing Groundwater Resources, 2012 GTRWO-86a and 2012 GTRWO-86b) were done at site specific locations within this allotment with the involvement of Fremont-Winema employees including several Antelope Grazing DEIS team members and were available years before this DEIS came out for public comment. The content of these proposed directives and the underlying protocol represent the best available science and should have guided analysis but did not. The agency did not use the science presented or incorporate recommendations from the Proposed Directives for Managing Ground Water Resources and their foundation documents or the agency’s own protocol, 2012 GTRWO-86b.  The hydrology report uses USDA Forest Service. 2012a. Groundwater-Dependent Ecosystems: Level II Inventory Field Guide. Gen. Tech. Report WO-86b (References, p. 54)  JG-52  Furthermore, the limited data set analyzed in the BEs and Specialist Reports was collected during 2010 and 2011, without consideration of more severe drought years that have caused precipitous declines in water tables and put GDE environments at new risk. Dr. Dewey and Dr. Cummings’ measurements indicate water table declines since 2010 and 2011. Furthermore, all 5 developed water sources at fens failed this summer due to lowered water tables from grazing and extended drought making the DEIS reliance on the Aldous and Gurrieri 2012 findings completely fallible. The DEIS fails to take a hard look at these changed conditions or analyze the potential new or unexamined impacts to GDE habitats from grazing as a result of multiple years of drought conditions.  While limited winter snow pack may have contributed to the reduced potential for soil water availability we cannot contribute the effects directly to livestock grazing.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The Botanical Report on page 13 discusses the use of water from fens within the project area for livestock, “Existing studies indicate water extraction for livestock is not causing drying of fen habitats in the project area. A study conducted at Johnson, Dry, and Wilshire Fens concluded that pumping water out of the fens to livestock troughs at a rate of 0.7 gpm (gallons per minute) or less did not result in lowering the groundwater table (Gurrieri et al., 2011). 0.7 gpm is approximately 3 times the average pumping rate used at those locations under current grazing management. Many of the fens in the project area are larger and wetter than the study sites.”  JG-53  See also previous “failure to use best available science” comments Goodwin et. al. Objection July 2014, pages 16-18; Goodwin et. al. Appeal April 2013, pages 29-30; Goodwin et. al. Comments January 2014 on page 11; and Simpson Declaration at paragraph 66 that more fully describe issues relating to this comment.  These comments are included in the project record.  JG-54  Specialist reports and analyses are going on 2-3 years old and are outdated. The Antelope IDT must go back to redesign alternatives and project design criteria. The IDT must follow the Forest Service’s own directives and protocol 2012 GTRWO-86b that use the best available science for managing groundwater resources and incorporate the available site specific expertise and data that Dr. Cummings and Dr. Dewey have available to develop new alternatives that protect fen habitats. The IDT must complete an adequate analysis of impacts to GDEs and associated sensitive species using the best available science.  Reports were reviewed for updated information and the Wildlife Report was updated to reflect a change in conditions.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-55  This DEIS is based on fatally flawed analyses and impact determinations for sensitive species (identified in the botany and wildlife biological evaluations BEs) that are dependent on ground water dependent ecosystems (GDEs). Without a thorough comprehensive analysis, any effects determination is arbitrary and capricious, and there is no basis to make a decision.  Data collection, science used, and effects analyses are discussed in the Wildlife Report and Biological Evaluation, the Botany Report and Biological Evaluation, and the other supporting reports for this project.  JG-56  For the following reasons, FP Goals, Objectives and S&G’s for threatened or sensitive species, are not being met under the DEIS.  Comment noted  JG-57  Analyses of GDE habitats are inadequate as described in the previous comments. Analyses do not identify all the key species specific habitat variables (such as distinct preferences for water levels and water chemistry and each species’ differing toleration of grazing, trampling, or sediment from hoof action). Analyses did not assess the direct, indirect, and cumulative impacts of grazing on all of these key habitat variables and species biophysical requirements as required under NEPA. Without such information, there is no way to tell which or to what extent sensitive GDE species are impacted by grazing and no way for the Forest Service to achieve compliance with FP requirements to evaluate and maintain sufficient habitat for sensitive species, among other requirements.  Data collection, science used, and effects analyses are discussed in the Wildlife Report and Biological Evaluation, the Botany Report and Biological Evaluation, and the other supporting reports for this project.  JG-58  The cumulative effects analyses on individuals or habitat, particularly with regard to the long term population trends, additive damage to soils and altered hydrology from livestock grazing, are incomplete, do not analyze critical impacts, and thus draw unsupported conclusions on cumulative impacts to sensitive GDE species.  Cumulative effects are described and analyzed for each resource in Chapter 3 of the FEIS.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-59  See also Simpson Comments October 2012 on pages 1-27; Goodwin et. al. Appeal April 2013 pages 22-32; Goodwin et. al. Comments January 2014 analysis and determination comments on pages 2, 4-6, 10, 11; Goodwin et. al. Objection July 2014, page 18 and Simpson Declaration at paragraphs 66 through 76 for more detailed comments on the above point.  These comments are included in the project record.  JG-60  The Antelope IDT must go back to redesign alternatives and project design criteria. The IDT must follow the Forest Service’s own directives and protocol 2012 GTRWO-86b that use the best available science for managing groundwater resources and incorporate the available site specific expertise and data that Dr. Cummings and Dr. Dewey have available to develop new alternatives that protect fen habitats. The IDT must complete an adequate analysis of impacts to GDEs and associated sensitive species using the best available science.  The hydrology report uses USDA Forest Service. 2012a. Groundwater-Dependent Ecosystems: Level II Inventory Field Guide. Gen. Tech. Report WO-86b (References, p. 54). This project had two scoping periods (11/01/2010 and 09/26/2011) because the Forest felt there was enough change between the original proposed action and the modified that it would be appropriate to scope again. Using the process for NEPA compliance, if an EA cannot determine whether effects are non-significant, or if effects are unknown, an EIS will be prepared. This would occur after the scoping period (FSH 1909.15_11.6, Exhibit 01, p. 19). A third scoping period was deemed unnecessary because the proposed action did not change again. Scoping was held early in the process, the proposed action was presented, and issues were identified and used to create alternatives. Comments received during the comment period did not present any concerns different than those presented during the September 2011 scoping period.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-61  Alternatives 2, 3 and 5 will continue to harm soils and hydrologic regimes in sensitive species habitats associated with GDEs and impede habitat recovery from past grazing damage threatening the viability of sensitive fen species.  Effects of Alternatives 3 and 5 to soils and hydrology are disclosed in sections 3.7 and 3.5, respectively, of the DEIS.  JG-63  For the following reasons, FP Goals, Objectives and S&G’s for threatened or sensitive species, are not being met under the DEIS Alternatives 2, 3 and 5. The DEIS and specialist reports state that harm to sensitive GDE species and their habitats have been occurring and will continue to occur and that past soil damage will recover more slowly, if at all, than the rates that grazing-excluded areas recover. Much of the harm to wet soils and altered hydrology from grazing is long term and additive. Degraded or destroyed habitat conditions reduce sensitive species thriftiness and ability to survive.  Comment noted  JG-64  Analysis of altered hydrologic regimes, often associated with soils damage and long term drought, is virtually absent from the specialist reports and DEIS. Negative effects from past grazing are readily apparent and the hydrology specialist report identifies numerous negative grazing effects that will continue to occur including pedestaling, bare soil, and soil compaction. Furthermore, the botany report documents that approximately 1/3 of fens surveyed were rated fair or poor due to soil disturbance. The soils report admits that seven fens surveyed did not meet Forest Plan soil productivity objectives.  The Hydrology report identifies the Affected Environment and effects of the various alternatives and this is summarized in the FEIS (pp.3-114 – 3128).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-65  By permitting grazing on these perennially wet habitats, the Forest ignores its own Winema Forest Plan soils and riparian S&G’s, its own soils range readiness criteria, and the best available science as presented in May 2014 Proposed Directives for Groundwater Resources that require it to manage habitats to maintain viable species populations and protect and provide for health of vegetation, soils, and wildlife, including hydrologic systems in wetlands, among other requirements. As a result, this DEIS fails to take a hard look, as required by NEPA, at impacts to soils and hydrologic regimes and does not provide adequate sensitive species and riparian habitat resource protection for alternatives 2, 3 and 5.  Chapter 2 of the FEIS identifies the Alternatives considered for this project, including Design Features and Implementation and Effectiveness Monitoring for the action alternatives. An Adaptive Management Strategy has been developed to examine and adjust grazing practices across the allotments. The Range and Nonforested Vegetation analysis (FESI pp.3-12 – 3-18), the Botanical Resources and Invasive Plants analysis (pp. 3-31 – 3-65), the Wildlife analysis (pp. 3-72 – 3-80 OSF), the  Hydrology analysis (pp. 3-119 – 3-128), the Fisheries analysis (3-134 – 3-141), and the Soils analysis (pp. 3-150 – 3-163) address the effects of grazing to the Forest Standards and Guidelines.  JG-66  Alternatives 2, 3 and 5 in this DEIS would likely cause irreparable harm to wet soils and hydrologic function in peatland GDEs, key habitat components for several very rare, geographically isolated sensitive species with very small population levels. This irreparable harm would move these species toward listing under the Endangered Species Act. Alternatives 2, 3 and 5 would also likely cause an irretrievable loss of GDE habitat for rare sensitive species in the area that would also move these species toward listing.  Effects analyses of GDEs are detailed in section 3.5.2.2.1 (p. 3-120) of the DEIS and pages 39–40 of the hydrology specialist report.  See also Simpson Comments October 2012 on pages 1-27; Goodwin  Please see response to JG-66 as this is a  et. al. Appeal April 2013 pages 22-32; Goodwin et. al. Comments  continuation of that comment.  JG-67  January 2014 soils and hydrology comments on pages 5-10, 23, 29;  Goodwin et. al. Objection July 2014 page 19; and Simpson  Declaration at paragraphs 36-76 for more detailed comments.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-68  The Antelope IDT must go back to redesign alternatives and project design criteria. The IDT must follow the Forest Service’s own directives and protocol 2012 GTRWO-86b that use the best available science for managing groundwater resources, and incorporate the available site specific expertise and data that Dr. Cummings and Dr. Dewey have available to develop new alternatives that protect fen habitats. The IDT must complete an adequate analysis of impacts to GDEs and sensitive species associated with them using the best available science.  Please see the “References” section of the DEIS. This project had two scoping periods (11/01/2010 and 09/26/2011) because the Forest felt there was enough change between the original proposed action and the modified that it would be appropriate to scope again. Using the process for NEPA compliance, if an EA cannot determine whether effects are non-significant, or if effects are unknown, an EIS will be prepared. This would occur after the scoping period (FSH 1909.15_11.6, Exhibit 01, p. 19). A third scoping period was deemed unnecessary because the proposed action did not change again. Scoping was held early in the process, the proposed action was presented, and issues were identified and used to create alternatives. Comments received during the comment period did not present any concerns different than those presented during the September 2011 scoping period. Also see response to comment JG-47.  JG-69  An adequate species viability analysis was not done for this DEIS as required in FP Goal 7 page 4-6 and S&G 4-1 on page 4-47.  “Provide habitat for viable populations of all existing native and desired non-native vertebrate species.” (Winema Forest Plan, Goal #7, p. 4-6), “At the Forest level, fish and wildlife habitat shall be managed to maintain viable populations of all existing native and desired non-native plant and animal species. Distribution of habitat shall provide for species viability and maintenance of populations throughout their existing range on the forest.” (Winema Forest Plan, p. 4-47)  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The Forest Service manages habitat for species associated with the Forest ecosystems. The Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife and/or the US Fish and Wildlife Service are charged with managing the species. Analysis of habitat for wildlife species is covered in the Wildlife Report and summarized in the FEIS, pp. 3-66 – 3-96. Design Features (pp. 2-31 – 2-36), adaptive management strategy and monitoring requirements (FEIS Appendix D) have been identified to maintain wildlife habitat.  JG-70  The GDE sensitive species viability conclusions in the Botany Report are unfounded and inaccurate. The botany BE concludes that cattle grazing will beneficially impact, have no impact on, or may impact habitat or individuals but is unlikely to cause a loss of viability of the populations. See Botany BE at 123-133. These conclusions are unfounded because they lack actual descriptions of species viability requirements and potential, and because their assessment criteria are incomplete and disconnected from the species-specific habitat requirements.  Tables A-5 and A-6 (Appendix A of the Botany Report, pp. 123-133) summarize the analysis of effects for Sensitive Terrestrial Mollusk and Insect Species (Table A-5) and Sensitive Plant Species (Table A-6). This analysis and effects determination, for all alternatives, is described on pages 27 through 87 (Botany Report).  JG-71  A population viability analysis must address evolutionary potential, demographic sustainability, ecological function, species social dynamics, historic range of habitat variability within the ecosystem, and maximum population level/carrying capacity of the ecosystem. The viability analysis should determine quantifiable objectives upon which to base management goals and measure progress toward those goals for a given population. This analysis would lay the foundation for determining whether habitat requirements sufficient to maintain the species are being met.  The Botany Report identifies the affected environment for sensitive plants, mollusks, and insects (pp. 3 – 15). It also presents the effects analysis of implementing the various alternatives, including impact determinations (pp. 27 – 87). The Wildlife Report identifies habitat requirements and affected environment for OSF on pages 29 – 31, and 36 – 44. The effects analysis is on pages 53 – 103. Sensitive species are covered on pages 103 – 120.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-72  The Botany report fails to discuss these species-specific viability factors. The assessment criteria used in the report (soil disturbance) are disconnected from each species’ site-specific habitat requirements, so do not actually assess the impacts to those requirements, and accordingly, do not assess the impacts to viability of each species. The viability determinations also lack quantifiable habitat or population objectives for any species and information on whether the current populations are at, above or below those objectives. Without this information, there is no way to determine what the impact of grazing is on the viability of these species as required in the Forest Plan.  Viability determinations are made in the botanical report. Section 3.2.3.2.2 (pp 3-57 through 3-64) discusses project effects to vitality for sensitive species.  JG-73  Many of the sensitive GDE species found in this project area have very small, confined, geographic distribution and low population levels. These are classic characteristics of species with low genetic diversity and high potential to become extinct. (It should be noted that limited geographic distribution, low population levels and low genetic diversity are often foundation reasons for listing a species under the Endangered Species Act.) Loss of a single individual in the project area, either from direct grazing harm or habitat degradation/loss, could represent an irretrievable loss of genetic coding essential to the long term survival of the species.  Please see responses to comments 69–72.  JG-74  See Simpson Comments October 2012 on pages 1 and 23, Goodwin et. al. Appeal April 2013 pages 22-29, Goodwin et. al.
