Effects of the alternatives on sensitive species is disclosed in the wildlife section (section 3.3) of the DEIS. Please see response to JG-69.  JG-76  Eliminating grazing with alternatives 1 or 4 would provide best protection and recovery for GDEs. DEIS page 3-122 says "Of the proposed alternatives, Alternative 1 would lead to the greatest improvements in hydrologic resources. In areas where livestock grazing has negatively impacted the land, livestock exclusion has consistently resulted in the most dramatic and rapid rates of ecosystem recovery (Belsky et al. 1999)."  Comment noted.  JG-77  DEIS 3-152 says "Research concludes that eliminating grazing is the best alternative for realizing the most rapid improvement on deteriorated landscapes (USDI BLM 2006). When allotments or pastures are rested (ungrazed), stream riparian habitats can regain productivity faster than if grazed (Platts and Nelson 1989). Recovery is quick, especially in the first few years after grazing is eliminated. Wyman (USDI BLM 2006) found that excluding livestock improved riparian habitat within 4 to 7 years. High levels of streambank and vegetation recovery was observed following 4 years of rest from grazing."  A no action alternative that eliminates grazing was analyzed in the range of alternatives (section 2.3 [Alternatives Considered in Detail], section 2.3.7 [Design Features], section 2.3.8 [Monitoring Elements] and Appendix D).  JG-78  DEIS 3-153 says "Round Meadow; the fenced areas of Rider’s Camp, Dry Meadow, Johnson fen and Little Round Meadow are but a few examples of riparian areas where recovery occurred after livestock grazing was eliminated through resource protection fencing or from lack of use. Removing grazing activities from the project area would likely result in similar impacts to those realized in the currently ungrazed portions of the project area."  Comment noted  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-79  Pages 41-42 of the hydrology report admits: "The removal of grazing under Alternative 1 would provide for the greatest improvements to hydrologic resources. Soil compaction resulting from trampling of soil by cattle would no longer occur, and vegetation cover would increase once livestock grazing ceased. Existing soil compaction would decrease over time due to root growth and expansion and frequent freezethaw cycles. The increase in vegetation cover and reduction in soil compaction would have the potential to increase soil water infiltration and storage and decrease overland flow. Existing water structures would not be maintained, and there would be the possibility of increased streamflow in Jack Creek. The increase in streamflow would have the potential to add perennial streamflow to sections of Jack Creek that currently flow intermittently,.. ... In conclusion, implementation of Alternative 1 would lead to the greatest improvements in hydrologic resources of all alternatives. In areas where livestock grazing has negatively impacted the land, livestock exclusion has consistently resulted in the most dramatic and rapid rates of ecosystem recovery (Belsky et al., 1999)."  “The removal of grazing under Alternative 1 would provide for the greatest improvements to hydrologic resources. Soil compaction resulting from trampling of soil by cattle would no longer occur, and vegetation cover would increase once livestock grazing ceased. Existing soil compaction would decrease over time due to root growth and expansion and frequent freeze-thaw cycles. The increase in vegetation cover and reduction in soil compaction would have the potential to increase soil water infiltration and storage and decrease overland flow. Existing water structures would not be maintained, and there would be the possibility of increased streamflow in Jack Creek. The increase in streamflow would have the potential to add perennial streamflow to sections of Jack Creek that currently flow intermittently, however this would be unlikely due to the porous geology of the project area.” (Hydrology Report, p. 41)  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  “While the implementation of Alternative 1 would lead to the greatest improvements to hydrologic resources, some negative impacts would still occur. For example, private parcels along Jack Creek at Moffit, Upper Jamison, and Lower Jamison would not be waived for grazing management to the NFS under a term/private grazing permit. As grazing would not occur on NFS lands, there would be potential for increased grazing intensity along the 3 mile private section of Jack Creek (Table 17), which could negatively impact water quality and channel morphology in Jack Creek on NFS land downstream from the private lands. Monitoring of key areas would no longer occur and long-term trends in allotment health would remain unknown. Some short-term (1-2 years) ground disturbance would occur during removal of fences between pastures and around currently fenced riparian areas, however the impacts would be minimal.” (Hydrology Report, p. 42)  JG-80  AUMs The DEIS fails to disclose the basis for determining AUMs for any pastures. It fails to take into account that improved breeding has resulted in larger animals and increased animal units for the same number of animals. It fails to discuss the downward trend in available AUMs since 1970. It also fails to discuss changes in climate that are driving extended drought, more extreme variation in annual forage production and a trend toward lower annual forage production. As a result, it is impossible for the Public to determine whether proposed alternatives are ecologically sustainable, practical, or even feasible.  The project complies with Fremont Forest Plan objectives (USDA Forest Service 1989, p. 65) that Animal Unit Months will remain close to existing levels, proper livestock use of available forage will be emphasized  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  There are no requirements in the Forest Service Manual (1920) or Forest Service Handbook (1909) to determine AUMs for a grazing NEPA analysis. Regardless of the number of AUM’s available livestock management is based upon implementing the Forest Plan Grazing standards (Winema FP pages 4-62 thru 4-63) livestock are removed from the area once utilization standards have been met. If proper use levels are met across the allotment prior to authorize off dates livestock are required to be removed from the Forest. The Nonforested Vegetation and Range Report analyzes the expected effects of grazing on nonforested vegetation and range for each alternative by grazing levels and season of use (pp. 36–66).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-81  This DEIS analysis appears to rely largely on historic AUM’s used rather than determining AUM’s based on current conditions. A review of the process records and FOIA records shows that a single range analysis was done in 2008 for the Chemult Pasture, but no others were done elsewhere. Without this analysis for each pasture, there is no basis to make a determination how many AUMs can be permitted. The 2008 analysis is outdated. Given the multiple years of severe drought since then, it’s reasonable to assume that the number of AUMs available is down. This assumption is supported by the trend in the Chemult Pasture that can be seen from a review of FOIA records: in 1970 there were 1341 AUMs, available, in 1995 1200 AUM’s, and the 2008 Antelope Allotment Range Analysis says 1050 AUMs in the Chemult Pasture. This could be a result of drought or overgrazing, or both, but the DEIS doesn’t say. The DEIS must disclose what is causing this downward trend and take appropriate action to respond to it instead of ignoring it.  Project area current conditions were determined using data detailed in Nevill and Robson (2001) who conducted a range analysis of the Antelope Allotment and published their data in 2011. The Forest Service permits use on National Forest system lands based upon occupancy and implantation of grazing standards. Regardless of the number of AUM’s available livestock management is based upon implementing the Forest Plan Grazing standards (Winema FP pages 4-62 thru 4-63) livestock are removed from the area once utilization standards have been met. If proper use levels are met across the allotment prior to authorize off dates livestock are required to be removed from the Forest. Data collection/Methodology are described on pages 19 – 34 of the Nonforested Vegetation and Range Report.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Some reductions in potential “available” AUM’s were due to the implementation of several “exclosures” across the allotment implemented by former Chemult district wildlife biologist Terry Simpsom. While the appropriate NEPA process was not followed to implement these exclosures and the permittee was never given the opportunity to appeal these as required under FSH 2209.13, Chapter 10, Section 16 pages 27-29, in accordance with 36 CFR 251, Subpart C; adjustments were not made in the permitted numbers. The 2005 letter from the then Forest Supervisor, Karen Shimamoto discusses the fact that the exclosures that were put in place were “ intent for the fence structures placed around the wet meadow and riparian systems are to serve as grazing time-control structures, and not intended to entirely exclude the forage base from grazing.” However that has been what has happened over time. These exclosures are still part of the available forage base for the allotment and therefore the capacity is still available despite the fact they are not currently being used., However, as evidenced in the administrative record and documented in the annual end of season monitoring reports the permittee has still been able to meet the required Forest Plan standards and guides for utilization across the remaining areas still available to grazing.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-82  Pastures within this project area are not irrigated and are completely dependent upon water arriving at the appropriate growing season. The changes in amounts and timing of precipitation have a dramatic effect on annual plant growth, and thus the number of AUMs available annually. The DEIS makes no mention of this range in variation dependent on annual precipitation.  Section 3.10 of the DEIS discusses climate change, including trends of annual precipitation (Table 3-32). In addition, section 2.3.8 and Appendix D detail the monitoring plan that will drive grazing.  JG-83  The Little Declaration talks about herd genetic improvements with the result that since 2008 the size of cattle turned out has increased. The DEIS does not disclose how many animal units per cow/calf pair. Even though the number of cattle turned out has not increased as stated in the DEIS, the number of animal units has increased. Thus the number of AUMs needed to support them for the same length of grazing season have also increased.  The project complies with Fremont Forest Plan objectives (USDA Forest Service 1989, p. 65) that Animal Unit Months will remain close to existing levels, proper livestock use of available forage will be emphasized. There are no requirements in the Forest Service Manual (1920) or Forest Service Handbook (1909) to determine AUM’s for a grazing NEPA analysis.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-84  An ocular estimate of the average weight of a cow/calf pair turned out onto the Chemult Pasture last year is between 1500 to 2000 pounds, or 1.5 to 2 animal units per pair. A quick calculation using 1.5 to 2 animal units per pair shows that between 1575 and 2100 AUMs are needed to support 350 pairs for 3 months in the Chemult Pasture (alternative 5). This is one and a half to two times the number of AUMs needed for this number of animals for this amount of time than the 1050 AUMs available as stated in the range analysis for the Chemult Pasture. Clearly alternative 5 is not feasible based on the number of AUMs needed and what is available. Neither are alternatives 2 and 3.  The Forest Service is unaware of any scientifically meaningful or accurate way for determining weight of livestock by “ocular estimate”, the commenter over estimates their ability to accurately determine livestock weights just by looking at them. The commenter clearly does not understand the process by which AUM’s are calculated. AUM’s are based upon a daily dry matter intake of forage, it is not a one-to-one ration conversion for animal weight to AUM’s. Daily dry matter intake varies depending upon factors such as; class of livestock, time of year, animal nutrient requirements (stage of gestation or lactation), and quality of forage. Average consumption rates range from 25-30 pounds of daily dry matter forage per animal per day. The more appropriate way to determine forage needs is to use this figure and calculate the forage needs for the grazing season. So, one cow/calf pair needs 25-30lbs/per day multiplied by the number of days in a grazing season multiplied by the number of livestock to be grazed will determine the total amount of forage required to sustain the permitted livestock numbers for the permitted season. (For example: 1 c/c pair for 30 days consuming an average of 27.5lbs per day would consume 825 lbs of forage. That same cow would need 2475 lbs of forage for an average 90 day grazing season.)  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The Forest Service permits use on National Forest system lands based upon occupancy and implementation of grazing standards. Regardless of the number of AUMs available livestock management is based upon implementing the Forest Plan Grazing standards (Winema FP pages 4-62 thru 4-63) livestock are removed from the area once utilization standards have been met. If proper use levels are met across the allotment prior to authorize off dates livestock are required to be removed from the Forest, because of this the Forest Service does not guarantee a permittee will be able to graze for the full duration of any season.  JG-85  The trend in forage production and the number of AUMs it will support is going down while the number of animal units and AUMs needed to support the herd is increasing. The DEIS has failed to analyze these factors. This information is critical to develop alternatives that are feasible and ecologically sustainable.  The project complies with Fremont Forest Plan objectives (USDA Forest Service 1989, p. 65) that Animal Unit Months will remain close to existing levels, proper livestock use of available forage will be emphasized. The Forest Service permits use on National Forest system lands based upon occupancy and implementation of grazing standards. Regardless of the number of AUM’s available livestock management is based upon implementing the Forest Plan Grazing standards (Winema FP pages 4-62 thru 4-63) livestock are removed from the area once utilization standards have been met. If proper use levels are met across the allotment prior to authorize off dates livestock are required to be removed from the Forest.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-86  Range of Alternatives The DEIS fails to provide a reasonable range of alternatives. None of the alternatives adequately address the need for recovery, restoration and protection actions.  There is currently a “no grazing” alternative being proposed for the analysis. This alternative responds to this concern. “No action” is synonymous with “no grazing” and means that livestock grazing would not be authorized within the project area. (FSH 2209.13–92.31). Furthermore, Oregon spotted frog recovery efforts are independent of the Antelope Grazing allotment NEPA project. Analysis of the effects of restoration was considered in cumulative effects, including for the no action alternative as required by NEPA.  JG-87  The DEIS at 2-2 Alternatives Eliminated from Detailed Study, 2.2.4 Alternative D—Restoring and Protecting Allotment states: “The IDT considered this alternative in response to comments that resources within the allotment needed restoration and protection. This alternative would recover the Jack Creek Oregon spotted frog population, restore and protect fens and associated species, permanently exclude grazing within existing fenced meadows, restore Round Meadow, maintain existing allotment boundaries, and complete Oregon spotted frog restoration projects.”  Section 2.2.4 of the DEIS details why Alternative D was not carried forward for detailed study.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The IDT eliminated this alternative proposed by the public because “…this alternative would be outside the scope of the project, and its various elements were either infeasible or alternatively addressed in the alternatives analyzed in detail, this alternative was eliminated from detailed analysis.” A review of Background (page i) and Purpose and Need section (DEIS 1.2, pages 1-3 through 1-5) reveals all of the requirements and responsibilities could be fulfilled and goals and objectives could be met by a restoration/ recovery/ protection alternative but not in a grazing-centric way as the Fre-Win seems to prefer. Fencing of riparian systems may require concerted effort (DEIS page 2-1, 2.2.2) but certainly is feasible. Restoration and protection were not adequately analyzed within grazing alternatives 2, 3, and 5 or by eliminating cattle grazing (Alt. 1 and 4). Additional restoration and protection measures and projects may be required. One of the reasons given for not fencing riparian areas for restoration and protection was, “… an understanding of where sensitive riparian systems are located throughout the allotments was in conflict with statements received through public comments. Therefore the IDT was not able to identify the intent of the use of “riparian” within the public comments.” (DEIS at 2.2, page 2-2). The IDT could have simply consulted the Winema FP glossary (page 37) to identify riparians. The FP glossary defines riparian as, “Pertaining to areas of land directly influenced by water. Riparian areas usually have visible vegetative or physical characteristics reflecting this water influence.” Please analyze Alternative D—Restoring and Protecting Allotment in a supplemental DEIS or the FEIS (DEIS p.2-2).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JG-91  Walker Rim Groundwater Dependent Ecosystems Please designate the Walker Rim Groundwater Dependent Ecosystems area as a unique management area where viable habitats for sensitive and threatened species, public enjoyment and education, research, and the development of appropriate management standards are the highest priorities. In recent years, studies indicate the unusual hydrogeology of the Walker Rim area supports the largest concentration of fens (peatlands) in the Pacific Northwest. The unique combination of precipitation, pumice soils from the eruption of Mt. Mazama (Crater Lake), elevation, and topography has created groundwater dependent ecosystems (GDEs) that are home to many species of rare mollusks, bryophytes and vascular plants. Walker Rim’s hydrogeology also supports the headwaters of Jack Creek. From Cummings Declaration at 67-70, “… the unique wetland environments, including fens and perennial and seasonal wetlands on the Antelope C&H Allotment, were formed as the result of a unique confluence of hydrological, geological, and biological factors and changes that occurred over millennia. The hydrogeologic system underlying the Antelope Allotment that supports this amazing biotic diversity is unprecedented in the Pacific Northwest.” “However, the system is neither permanent nor invincible, and it is inherently transitory. Over time, the pumice that is a key element of its survival will erode from the landscape. Management practices that disrupt the fen and wetland ecosystems increase the rates of change, and shorten the time scales under which the system is evolving. Once disrupted, the fen system is very unlikely to return due to the ongoing hydrogeologic evolution of the area and the time it takes to redevelop these complex wetland environments.  The forest supervisor determines when to amend or revise the plan. Taking input from the public and monitoring results from the forest are considered when making the determination to amend or revise the plan now or wait for the next scheduled planning cycle.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  “Additionally, the supply of groundwater that sustains this system is currently at a precarious tipping point due to a long-term drought. While the pumice has extraordinary storage capacity, the volume of water in the unconfined aquifer is largely dependent upon infiltration of snowmelt. The recent low water years, especially the most recent winter of negligible snowfall, make the GDE even more fragile than usual. “As a hydrogeologist, I greatly value the Walker Rim GDE area as an incredibly unique snapshot in hydrogeologic history of a volcanically disturbed landscape. I believe that studying the area in its current form will teach us a great deal about the hydrogeologic properties of pumice and its effects on development of ecosystems. Activities that disrupt those ecosystems alter the natural integrity of the overall system, and make it less valuable for scientific research.”  JG-95  Most of the GDE exclosures appear in good condition currently because they haven’t been grazed but long term damage remains. Unfenced GDEs will continue to be damaged by grazing. The grazing alternatives 2, 3, and 5 will graze fenced and unfenced GDEs. The grazing alternatives will quickly cause the same damage as initially created the needs for exclosures and the cycle of damage and recovery will begin again. Following are several photos showing GDEs proposed for grazing before fencing protection, results of grazing in exclosures proposed for grazing with breached fences in 2014, and unfenced GDEs that will continue be subjected to damaging grazing.  The EIS acknowledges the same impact. Photos are an indication of damage but there is no quantification of the extent of damage or how it relates to the research cited. The forest plan standards and guidelines are being met and damage to particular sensitive fens was considered by proposing additional exclosures and adaptive management.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Dry Meadow Soil Pedestals Before Protection – 2004  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Dry Meadow Headcut Before Protection – 2004 Cannon Meadow Before Protection – 2004  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Squirrel Camp Before Protection – 2005  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Squirrel Camp Before Protection – 2005 Sproats Meadow Before Protection – 2004  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Sproats Meadow cattle damage after water trough malfunction and fence breach – 2014  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Rider’s Camp (aka Cow Camp) Before Protection – 2005  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Rider’s Camp cattle damage after fence breached by cattle – 2014  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Crooked Meadow Unprotected Fen – 2014  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Lower Johnson Unprotected Fen – 2014  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Lower Johnson Unprotected Fen – 2014  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  East Johnson (9418-490) Unprotected Fen – 2013  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  East Johnson (9418-490) Unprotected Fen – 2013 East Sproats Unprotected Fen -2014  JG-97  We offer to partner with the Fre-Win to make restoration and protection for Jack Creek and the Walker Rim groundwater dependent ecosystems a high priority and provide certainty for longterm viability of spotted frogs and other sensitive species. Response to Comments for Mary Jo Hedrick No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  MH01  Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife (the Department) supports alternative 3 with the following recommendations to monitor impacts to significant plant, fish and wildlife habitats. The project area contains 620 acres of fen habitats. Fens support unique and rare plant species. Eight sensitive vascular plants and five sensitive bryophytes species were documented in the project area. There are seven miles of perennial stream (Jack Creek) and 287 miles of intermittent streams within the project area. Miller Lake lamprey a sensitive species and Oregon spotted frog a Federal proposed species are found throughout the perennial portion of Jack Creek. The project area contains 10,125 acres of winter range habitat within the Fort Rock Wildlife Management Unit.  Comment noted.  MH02  The Department supports grazing the Chemult and North Sheep pastures using deferred rotation and graze Jack Creek and the meadow units within the Chemult pasture using a deferred rotation riparian grazing system. This will allow better distribution of cattle across the landscape and increase flexibility in grazing management. The Chemult and North Sheep pastures contain approximately 3,985 and 1,095 acres respectively of riparian, moist to wet meadows, willow wetlands, fens, aspen stands and lodgepole wetlands in various seral stages. These habitats support a wide diversity of plants, fish and wildlife.  Comment noted. The deferred-rotation grazing system you describe was analyzed as Alternatives 3 and 5 in the DEIS.  Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  MH03  The eastern pastures (Halfway, North Willow and Tobin) receive less precipitation than the western pastures and many of the riparian areas and stock ponds are dry by late summer. Historically these pastures were rated in poor condition with the riparian areas trending downward. Riparian areas and springs in the eastern pastures continue to experience heavy use by cattle but remain within Forest standards and guidelines. In addition, grazing within the riparian areas could negatively impact elk calving and mule deer fawning habitat. The Department supports monitoring riparian habitats through vegetation utilization, hydrologic and soil conditions. If any sign of downward trend in riparian habitat quality is observed grazing should be reevaluated.  The proposed pre-turnout monitoring would address soil conditions within identified sensitive areas. Section 3.7.1 of the EIS discusses the existing soil conditions within these sensitive areas and the specific management objectives and standards for resource protection of forest riparian areas in the Winema Forest Plan. The monitoring results would determine if and when grazing would occur within these areas. In addition, monitoring data will be used to develop Annual Operating Instructions for each grazing season. Monitoring data will allow the manager to evaluate annual grazing use levels against monitored trend and condition data. Long-term Monitoring data would also be used to validate grazing use (numbers and season) set in the grazing permit. The long-term monitoring data would assist in determining if additional adaptive management actions are warranted on the allotment and if numbers and season are appropriate for the allotment.  MH04  The Alternative 3 identifies 5 springs in need of reconstruction or improvements and 4 new spring developments. These spring developments should be fenced and water provided off site. In addition, the Department recommends the new water developments be located so access is available from open roads.  The Department recommends fences around springs and fens be constructed of wood; reducing the negative impacts to birds. In addition, the Department recommends springs within the allotment be inventoried, monitored and fenced if needed.  Surveys of 67 spring and fens throughout the project area were conducted from 2009 to 2011 (p. 4 of the botanical technical report). Necessary protection measures, such as fencing or caging of spring sources, were identified for each location. See Figures 2-2, 2-4, 2-6, 2-8, and 2-10 and Appendix D (Table 2) for details on locations, monitoring, and implementation proposals for spring protection.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  All structural range improvements will be constructed to Forest Services standards and will be designed accordingly to address potential issues with wildlife  MH05  A six year South Central mule deer study showed deer from the Fort Rock winter range migrate west towards Highway 97, thru the Antelope Allotment crossing numerous fences.  Fences not meeting wildlife standards have been documented to cause mortality and injure deer. The Department recommends any fence construction or reconstruction be to wildlife standards; reducing the negative impact to mule deer, pronghorn and elk.  Comment noted. All structural range improvements will be constructed to Forest Services standards and will be designed accordingly to address potential issues with wildlife.  MH06  Jack Creek contains Miller Lake lamprey a sensitive species and Oregon spotted frog a Federal proposed species. In addition to riparian habitat lamprey and spotted frog populations should be monitored.  If these populations show any sign of downward trend grazing should be reevaluated.  On page 3-81, the DEIS states the following regarding a monitoring plan for Oregon spotted frog: “A monitoring plan would accompany the implementation of these alternatives. This plan would consist of monitoring the different resources associated with the allotment and OSF, including but not limited to, hydrologic, range, and wildlife resources. Monitoring would be intended to evaluate progress toward the management goals, detect changes in the resources, and determine  trends in resource condition. The data collected would provide a basis for implementing adaptive management in order to meet the management objectives associated with this permitted action.” Effects from the project on Miller Lake lamprey are discussed in the fisheries technical report, beginning on page 32.   No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  MH07  The hydrology report indicates 7 of 8 unfenced fens were in poor condition while 10 of 11 fenced fens were in good condition. To minimize impacts to fens and their unique and rare plant species the Department supports Alternative 3 recommendations to fence these sensitive habitats. Fens outside of fenced riparian areas should be prioritized for fences and fens within meadows scheduled for grazing should be fenced prior to cattle reintroduction. In addition, the Department recommends fenced areas include a buffer around fens. Soil and vegetation maps could be used to determine location and placement of fences within the wet meadows.  See response to MH-04.  MH08  The Halfway and North Willow pastures are within the Fort Rock mule deer winter range. The Department has observed heavy bitterbrush utilization by cattle within these pastures. Utilization of bitterbrush by cattle reduces available forage for mule deer during fall migration and winter. Cumulative effects common to all alternatives identified in the Wildlife Report did not include prescribed fire. Numerous prescribed fires have been implemented within the eastern pastures and have substantially reduced the amount of bitterbrush available to wintering mule deer. The Department is concerned the earlier turn in dates in particular mid-May and increased duration of grazing in the Halfway pasture may increase bitterbrush utilization by cattle. The Department recommends monitoring bitterbrush utilization by cattle in these pastures and if needed grazing should be reevaluated.  Effects to mule deer, including effects to bitterbrush, are discussed in the wildlife technical report, beginning on page 108. As stated in the wildlife technical report (pg. 109), “Several studies have indicated that competition for forage between cattle and deer is minimal on properly stocked, moderately grazed ranges (Currie et al. 1977, McMahan 1964, Skovlin et al. 1968, and Austin and Urness 1986).”  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  MH09  The Chemult, North Sheep and Tobin pastures contain a known elk calving area. The EA applies two different elk calving dates one for the Winema and one for the Fremont. Cattle have been shown to influence the pattern of use by elk; elk avoid areas of cattle distribution. The Department’s recommended elk calving dates are May 15 through June 30 and recommends it be applied consistently throughout the allotment.  The Forest will follow the appropriate Forest Plan standards regarding any potential restrictions on time for both the Fremont and the Winema portions of the Forest. As stated on page 145 of the wildlife technical report, dates proposed for grazing within elk calving habitat would not overlap with the calving season, which is typically April 14 to  June 15. The Winema National Forest Land and Resource Management Plan standard and guideline 4-12 restricts road access and discourages human activities between May 1 and June 30.  MH10  The Department recommends cattle salt sights should be accessed from open roads were possible.  The Forest will implement the appropriate Forest Plan standards and guidelines regarding salting techniques/methods for allotment management. Project design features (section 2.3.7) prohibit salting in aspen areas, in riparian areas, and near developed water sources to comply with INFISH requirement GM-3.  MH11  Aspen woodlands support a wide diversity of wildlife. The Department has observed increased aspen regeneration in the North Sheep pasture. Grazing within Jack Creek, the meadow units and North Sheep pasture could negatively impact aspen stands and regeneration. Aspen utilization should be monitored and the aspen stands protected if needed.   The Forest will implement the appropriate Forest Plan standards and guidelines regarding browse use for allotment management planning purposes. Table 32 of the range technical report notes that browse utilization of woody species will be monitored and livestock will be moved to the next unit or off the allotment when utilization thresholds are reached.  MH12  Thank you for the opportunity to comment. Please free to contact me if you need additional information. Sincerely,  Thank you for your continued interest in this project.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Mary Jo Hedrick Asst. District Wildlife Biologist cc Craig Foster (ODFW) Thomas Collom (ODFW) Amy Markus (USFS)  Table 5. Response to Comments for James Linebaugh No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JL-01  Comments on the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS) for the Antelope Flat Grazing Allotments AMP Analysis Background and Interest in the Area My interest and experience in the Antelope/Jack Creek country goes back to the 1940s with my father who was a Forest Service rangeland field technician in the Silver Lake district. My family also held a grazing permit in these allotments for about thirty years and I had a share of cowboy duty there as a youngster. Since 1957 I have worked as a professional resource and rangeland manager with the US Dept of Agriculture, State of NV, the University of NV, and as a private consultant. My son and I are also owners of Stimson Meadow, a 640 acre inholding, where grazing use has been leased from us by neighboring Forest Service permittees and managed as part of the allotment for about forty years. This gives us a very personal interest in the area underscored by our desire to see well managed grazing continue on the private land as well as the national forest.  Thank you for your continued interest in this project.  Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JL-02  Some Personal Observations The grazing use season has been about the same over the years but both numbers of grazers and livestock have been greatly reduced. In the 1940s there were several permittees (cattle over 1000 head plus sheep season long and more trailing through). Now there is one cattle user with less than 500 head and almost no sheep. With greater numbers of livestock forage utilization was higher but with the limited season of use there was little long term resource damage. The forest situation has changed with harvest of much of the lodgepole and ponderosa pine. After harvest there was a temporary increase in understory vegetation but tree reproduction has filled in during the last two or three decades. Lodgepole has encroached in the meadows and needs to be removed. In the 1940s and fifties I remember numerous spotted frogs in the Jack Creek riparian area. The meadows were well grazed. It's hard to believe that grazing has been the cause of reduced frog numbers since they were more numerous when grazing use was greater. I and other knowledgeable observers have not reported the presence of spotted frogs on our private land. For the last decade or more the private land owner/permittee in the Jack Creek area has worked cooperatively with the Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service, and others interested to develop plans and management actions that favor the threatened Oregon Spotted Frog. It is well protected.  Comment noted. The EIS discusses the history of grazing within the project area in section 3.1 and the description, habitat, and life history of the Oregon spotted frog as well as the species vulnerability and threats to the species in section 3.3.1. .  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  JL-03  The Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DElS) Antelope Grazing Allotment This DEIS is quite comprehensive with great detail and thorough background information, including pertinent studies and research citations. I recommend Alternative 3 in a decision. The DEIS suggests Alternative 3 as the Proposed Action. This alternative is fully in accord with Forest Service authorities and regulatory guidance that provides for multiple use, including the positive impact of managed grazing with a stable to upward trend in desired rangeland condition, and positive area economic support. It also agrees with the Winema forest management plan which provides for grazing and its benefits in the multiple use mix. Some elements included in Alternatives 2 and 5 may also be selected and used in the AMP. Monitoring records generally indicate that rangeland vegetation/health throughout the allotment is static to improving. The allotment is quite capable of carrying the animals suggested in the DEIS.  Comment noted.  JL-04  Some Project and Management Actions to Keep in Mind I urge the Forest Service to allow for maximum flexibility and adaptive management. This will help facilitate short term changes in livestock presence depending on such as utilization levels and water avai1ability during the grazing season. Some fen and meadow areas are fenced or proposed for protection fencing to exclude livestock. Managed grazing should be allowed in these areas. Ungrazed meadow vegetation becomes decadent and unhealthy. Limit fencing and other projects like water developments to those really needed. Maintenance is always hard to keep up with. The Forest Service should help with construction and maintenance for projects with public benefits accruing beyond those for the grazier.  The project includes an adaptive management plan that uses a set of guidelines to implement management action on the allotment. The alternatives described in the EIS have a variety of resource protection fences and pasture/boundary fences proposed based upon resource objectives. Through monitoring of the fens, it was determined that the highest value fens will be protected.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Maintenance will be assigned according to Forest Service policy. If the improvements are designed for livestock control, boundary fences, pasture drift fences, or water developments the grazing permittee will be assigned maintenance responsibility, while those improvements installed as resource protection measure will be maintained by the Forest Service by the appropriate program area. (Forest Service Handbook 2241).  JL-05  Access for Maintenance and Grazing/Livestock Management The Forest Service is to be commended for recognizing the need for occasional vehicle travel for livestock management and facilities maintenance off established and designated routes. I am asking also that the same need be recognized for management of our private land and nearby national forest land. I have twice requested that access to our property from the South and East be recognized by including Forest Service Road 190 in the Travel Management Plan. This is also important for the Antelope permittee who has private property next to ours. Thank you for accepting and considering these comments as you move toward a decision on the Antelope Allotment. Sincerely, James A. Linebaugh CC: Marjorie Iverson and Keith Little James L. (Linc) Linebaugh  Transportation and access, including the access for the permittee have been analyzed in the EIS in section 3.8. Any additional transportation analysis that is required to reopen or to close additional roads is outside the scope of this project.  Table 6. Response to Comments for Keith Little No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  KL01  Thank you for the opportunity to review the draft "EIS". Please accept the following comments on behalf of Iverson Management Limited Partnership ("Iverson"): First, we want to say that we appreciate the Forest Service's decision to prepare an EIS on this decision. Given the level of controversy and litigation over the Antelope Allotment for the past few years, we think this was a positive development. We also appreciate the Forest Service's efforts to evaluate whether grazing can occur in new areas, including enclosures and the North Sheep pasture. Additionally, we appreciate the careful analysis the Forest Service has provided concerning potential interactions between livestock and meadow/fen sustains, sensitive and listed species, riparian areas, etc. Further, we are thankful for the ongoing dialogue we have had as we continue to partner with the Forest Service to work through areas where we .are seeking to reach agreement. We hope this dialogue will continue as you reach a final decision on the allotment management plan, and provide these comments with that goal in mind. We have reviewed the alternatives and are not able to endorse any one of them without reservations. Fortunately, the Forest Service's decision is not limited to adopting a single alternative. NEPA simply requires the Forest Service to evaluate its decision, which it has done here.. The Forest Service, having evaluated the matter, is thus able to issue a final decision that reflects that analysis, but can choose from various elements of the alternatives analyzed. We ask that the Forest Service ensure that the final decision be refined to address the concerns addressed below.  Comment noted. We thank you for your continued interest in this project.  Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Draft Environmental Impact Statement Appendix E—Response to Comments No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  KL03  Our primary concern is that the alternatives presented do not adequately account for forage availability and the practicalities of managing livestock on the Antelope Allotment and North Sheep Pasture (collectively referred to hereafter as the Antelope Allotment). We do not object to the Forest Service's efforts to improve range conditions and the health of ecosystems. However, in order to protect those systems and to ensure a reasonable and practical approach to grazing management, we must object to proposals that do not adequately reflect the history and current conditions of the local ecosystems. Our local knowledge of how the systems work as a result of our extensive on-the-ground perspective and knowledge is critical to ensuring that the design of the final decision will work-for the Forest Service and for Iverson Ranch. It ensures that the Forest Service's professionals are able to implement their knowledge about biological systems and conservation in ways that makes sense for the specifics of the allotment. We think it is immensely critical, therefore, for the Forest Service and Iverson Ranch to work as partners, using all of our knowledge to design a reasonable, practical approach to accomplishing multiple use goals on the forest. We offer these comments in that spirit.  Comment noted.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  KL04  One of our concerns is that a one-herd system will not work. Here are a few of our reasons for this concern: the allotment is large, the pastures are not sufficiently controlled, cow managers cannot easily see or locate cows because of lodge pole pine thickets, cows cannot be herded well enough to do a deferred rotation without fencing, adding more fences is time and cost prohibitive on this allotment. These practical realities and concerns have to be considered in the final decision. The Forest Service simply cannot implement a decision that asks Iverson Ranch to do what it cannot do. We need to design a decision that achieves multiple use goals without asking either Iverson Ranch or the Forest Service to do something they cannot do without setting them up for failure.  Federal agencies are required by NEPA to rigorously explore and objectively evaluate all reasonable alternatives and to briefly discuss the reasons for eliminating any alternatives that were not developed in detail (40 CFR 1502.14). Alternative 2 in the DEIS (section 3.5.2.4) proposes to continue permitted livestock grazing under the current management systems; only 3.6 miles (section 2.3.2.2) of fence is proposed for construction to reinforce the Chemult Pasture allotment boundary. Fence construction is proposed under the deferred-rotation alternatives. A phase implementation plan will been developed in cooperation with the grazing permittee and will be included in the Allotment Management Plan.  KL05  Proposed Rotation The following is a rotation we think makes sense on the ground for livestock management, based on forage availability, the timing of forage availability, the size of the allotment, the realities of moving cows on this allotment, and the existing and proposed fencing structure: Herd 1 Halfway Pasture 163 c/c May 15-June 15 Tobin Pasture and/or Sheep Pasture 163 c/c June 15-Sept. 30 Herd 2 North Willow 256 c/c June 1-July 1 Chemult 340 c/c July 1 -September 30  This rotation is similar to that proposed under Alternative 5 and not too dissimilar to Alternative 3.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Herd 3 Jack Creek Riparian 75 c/c June 15-September 30  KL06  We think grazing in Antelope 2, 3, and 4 should be as proposed in Alternative 5 Antelope 1 is grazed by another permittee so we offer no comment on it.  Comment noted.  KL07  The grazing levels and seasons proposal above reflects the realities of the ground at issue and forage available within the allotment. and it our alternative proposal for at least the following reasons: Halfway pasture does not have sufficient water developments to support more than 163 c/c from May 15-June 15. North Willow has more forage than Halfway and should be supporting the larger herd from June 1-July 1.  Section 3.7.2 of the EIS and the soils technical report analyze effects of grazing under each of the alternatives on soils.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  A deferred rotation system is unattainable on the Chemult pasture. The pasture does not have the infrastructure to support it, nor would we be able to maintain the infrastructure if it did. Cows are not "herdable," particularly the livestock that utilize the allotment. The type of cows that do well on this type of allotment are not mild, pasture cows that would be easily herded. For example, they are wily cows and are able to hide in the lodge pole/timber stands on the allotment to avoid even the most knowledgeable and experienced riders on the allotment. Further, water on this allotment is spread out. Livestock spread out to reach these various water sources. From an ecological perspective, the idea of a herded deferred rotation would be harmful as well. The constant herding will increase hoof impacts, soil disturbance, dust levels, more intense use of water resources. The general premise that a deferred rotation will improve conditions as a result of the deferral is unlikely to work because of the degree of heightened impacts. It is also of note that on the Chemult pasture, grazing under this system generally does not occur until after grass has gone to seed. As such, the forage health is protected even by season-long grazing.  KL08  Please note, we do not think Rock Springs should be added to Tobin Cabin. This idea came about as a means for increasing pasture in the Tobin pasture. However, that is not needed with the use of enclosures and North Sheep pasture. We think that Rock Springs should remain in Chemult pasture and be managed with a rider.  Comment noted.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  KL09  Proposed Fencing We think it is absolutely critical that any fence location or construction decisions be done in partnership and cooperation with Iverson Ranch. They also need to be done as a cost share. Fences should be constructed in accordance with the Interagency Fence Guidelines, allowing the Forest Service and Iverson Ranch to make reasonable, on-the-ground decisions about how and where fences will be constructed. Iverson supports an incremental and rotating approach to fence construction and fence maintenance, particularly given that the type of maintenance often required on the allotment is more like reconstruction.  The implementation of any structural improvements will follow the appropriate Forest Service policy governing construction/maintenance of structural range improvements. The Forest Service will provide material for construction of new improvements it will be up to the permittee to provide the labor/construction costs to build the improvements. The permittee will be required to maintain all improvements to the appropriate forest service standards as required by the terms and conditions of the grazing permit.  As always, the Forest Service will work cooperatively with the permittee on placement and timing of the improvements to be constructed.  KL10  We also think that the right of way for fences should be more than 4 feet where necessary to improve the ability of the Forest Service and Pennittee to maintain the fences in a practical, economical, effective manner.  The DEIS states that constructed and reconstructed fences would require a minimum, not a maximum, 4-foot right-of-way clearance on each side (section 3.7.1.2.3).  KL11  With regards to the boundary fence for the North Sheep pasture, we suggest a different approach. The length of fence proposed is costly and will be difficult to maintain. Instead, let's take an approach that reflects adaptive management, a goal of reduced structures, and good livestock management. We suggest strategically placing drift fences. Our estimates are that this would require approximately 3.5 miles offences. To the extent they do not work, we can work together and adaptively to make changes. This is a more practical, resource-sensitive (time, costs, and environment) than a fence that spans the border of the entire pasture boundary.  See comment KL-09  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  KL12  Exclosures We appreciate the Forest Service's willingness to construct, reconstruct, and maintain exclosure fences. The implementation of any structural improvements will follow the appropriate Forest Service policy governing construction/maintenance of structural range improvements. The Forest Service will provide material for construction of new improvements it will be up to the permittee to provide the labor/construction costs to build the improvements. The permittee will be required to maintain all improvements to the appropriate forest  service standards as required by the terms and conditions of the grazing permit.  The Forest Service will prioritize the existing/proposed resource protection fences for maintenance to better insure they are being maintained adequately.  KL13  We also would ask that the Forest Service address impacts to forage availability from the exclosures, many of which are in important, high value forage areas, or the potential for livestock to impact resources adjacent exclosures fences when they are built, particularly where they exclose forage or water historically utilized by livestock. More rest is not an acceptable proposition for Iverson either from a science and preservation of OSF perspective, or from an economic perspective. In some cases, 35% is the move trigger. This generally equates to a 4" stubble height end point on indicator species in key areas. Iverson Ranch objects to a 25 to 35% riparian area utilization standard for any part of the allotment, and particularly on its private lands. This level of utilization standard unnecessarily restricts grazing and reduces plant health without an attendant benefit. Oregon Spotted Frog (OSF) counts are consistently higher on Iverson's private lands as compared  The Jack Creek Oregon Spotted Frog (Rana pretiosa) Site Management Plan (p. 52 of the Plan discusses utilization standards) will be used as the principle management tool to implement management within OSF habitat. Grazing standards within OSF habitat will need to be consistent with this plan and the terms and conditions of the Biological Opinion issued by the USFWS.  to Forest Service lands. Iverson grazes to a 55-65% utilization level on its private lands. The best available science and commercial data supports a moderate level of grazing to benefit OSF, and the results on the Iverson private ground indicate that 45-50% use is beneficial to OSF. The final decision should encourage grazing to at least a 3545% standard.  KL20  Iverson is also not agreeable to limiting late season grazing and particularly on its private lands, especially the Moffitt private pasture. The Moffitt private pasture has been grazed in the late season for many years and OSF are doing good and possibly better on this ground than on public lands in the Jack Creek riparian pastures. Further, the late season grazing is needed for Iverson's operations. We have been successful in preventing livestock from bedding down  According to Design Features WI(3,5)-4, late-season grazing in occupied Oregon spotted frog habitat is discouraged to project metamorphosing spotted frogs. According to the Jack Creek Oregon Spotted Frog (Rana pretiosa) Site Management Plan (p. 10), petamporphosis usually occurs in August and September in Jack Creek.  within meadow areas using salt blocks near water troughs on our private ground. This important tool should be noted and considered as a management option where appropriate to lessen impacts to wet meadows.  The Jack Creek Oregon Spotted Frog (Rana pretiosa) Site Management Plan (p. 51–56) will be used as the principle management tool to implement management within OSF habitat.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  KL21  Iverson Ranch can support a grazing rotation between private and public parcels, but objects to fencing the pasture into four separate sub-pastures. Grazing is a helpful tool in achieving habitat goals provided cattle are properly handled, even in Oregon Spotted Frog habitat. Iverson is not agreeable to the reduction of the grazing period by half a month, from 3.5 to 3 months. This reduction is not supported by existing literature, information about the pasture, or the Jack Creek Site Plan.  The livestock that would be grazed in the Jack Creek Riparian Pastures are part of the total numbers of livestock proposed across the entire area and when not being grazed in the riparian pasture will be allowed to graze in the other units on the allotment. This capacity has already been accounted for in the analysis (see section 2.3.5 of the EIS for a description of Alternative 5).  KL24  Finally, Iverson is unable to support imposition of the automatic range readiness requirement onto the Jack Creek Riparian Pasture. The Site Plan suggests that earlier grazing may be appropriate and this option should not be excluded. Adaptive management is fundamentally important and Iverson Ranch's strong preference.  See the discussion of range readiness in the range technical report (p. 20).  KL25  Forest Plan Standards  As noted in section 1.8.1 of the EIS, this project complies with the Fremont and Winema Forest Plans. Compliance with soil and water standards and guidelines is discussed in the soils (pp. 1, 13, 17) and hydrology (pp. 21–22) technical reports.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Overall, we want to see the final decision be consistent with the Fremont Winema Forest Plan. Please maintain the flexibility and adaptive management approach it allows. With regards to Soil and Water Standards and Guidelines, please ensure that the final decision does not require the removal of livestock based on the condition of individual or a few fens. That would not, in our opinion, be consistent with the Forest Plan.  KL26  Lodgepole Encroachment Lodgepole pine encroachment and piled lodgepole are a frequent cause of livestock trailing in wetter areas. Further, it reduces forage and increases the difficulty of managing cows on the allotment. We would like to see the Forest Service commit to multiple thinnings that are meaningful to restoring and improving the use of resources in the next 10 years. Livestock do not prefer to walk through wet meadows or riparian areas. With improvement regarding the thickets and piles, livestock impacts could be reduced.  Restoration activities as described are outside of the scope of the grazing analysis being conducted.  We would encourage the commenter to discuss this with the appropriate Forest Service personal and provide recommendations/proposals on what they would like to see completed within the project area.  KL27  In summary, Iverson believes it is critical to stress the level of actual restoration and improvements the ranch has done and will do in collaboration with the Forest Service and other state and federal agencies. This is particularly important with the lack of federal resources and delays caused by agency process. We would like to see the final decision recognize more clearly the need for partnership with Iverson Ranch and the benefits it provides.  Comment noted.  KL28  More than anything else, though, we want to stress how important we think adaptive management of the allotment will be. We would like to see the final decision provide for adaptive management for the allotment, giving us and the Forest Service the ability to carefully and appropriately respond to unforeseen circwnstances. We ask that you more fully build this into the decision made.  Comment noted.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Thank you again for the opportunity to provide these comments. Should you have any questions, I would be happy to discuss them in person. Sincerely, Keith Little Manager Iverson Management Limited Partnership cc: Elizabeth E. Howard/Schwabe Williamson & Wyatt  Table 7. Recovery is quick, especially in the first few years after grazing is eliminated. Rider’s Camp, Dry Meadow, Johnson fen and Little Round Meadow are but a few examples of riparian areas where recovery occurred after livestock grazing was eliminated through resource protection fencing or from lack of use. Removing grazing activities from the project area would likely result in similar impacts to those realized in the currently ungrazed portions of the project area."  RN05  Alternative 4 is the only action alternative that is substantially consistent with the Winema National Forest Plan 4-12 which states “[t]he demand for livestock grazing will be met only when it does not conflict with other uses”.  All action alternatives were developed in order to provide grazing opportunities and to meet multiple-use objectives while addressing public concerns about the protection of the various resources in the project area. See Sections: 2.3.3 (pg 2-12); 2.3.4 (pg2-18); 2.3.5 (pg 2-23); 2.3.7 (pg 2-31 thru 2-34).  RN06  We also request that you analyze the once rejected but very relevant Restoration Alternative in a supplemental DEIS or the FEIS (DEIS p.2-2).  Rationale for why this alternative was considered but eliminated from detailed analysis is included in section 2.2.4.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  “The development of a full restoration alternative is outside the scope of this project because it does not respond to the purpose and need to determine whether the Forest Service should continue to authorize livestock grazing in the Antelope Grazing Allotments project area. Preliminary resource analysis did not indicate that these restoration actions are needed as mitigation for grazing to be reauthorized, though the protection of occupied Oregon spotted frog habitat during the restoration process has been recognized through a project design feature common to the alternatives analyzed in detail.”  “The remaining actions proposed in this alternative (protection of sensitive fens and associated species, permanent exclusion of grazing from existing fenced meadows, Round Meadow restoration, and maintenance of existing allotment boundaries) were carried forward and considered by the IDT during preliminary analysis.” EIS page 2-2  RN07  Since this December 2014 DEIS and supporting documents are identical or very similar to the Antelope Grazing Allotments Project Environmental Assessment dated December 2013 we are submitting the text and photo attachment from our previous EA comment dated January 11, 2014 as DEIS comment letter #1 and photo attachment (attached). We are also submitting a declaration by R. Nawa for the administrative record because it provides documented field observations that support many of our science based comments.  These documents will be included in the project record.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  RN08  The DEIS violates the National Environmental Policy Act 1. We object to biased, outdated, and scientifically unsubstantiated statements about the desirability of using livestock grazing to “manage” non-forested riparian plant and animal communities in the Antelope Allotments. Scientific controversy about grazing in riparian areas was not fully analyzed. The DEIS p. 1-4 states: “Forest Plans and best available science identify livestock grazing as a management tool to efficiently, effectively, and responsibly manage forage and non-forested plant communities on NFS lands.” (emphasis added) Contrary to this statement, the best available science reveals that sensitive riparian management areas need to be excluded from livestock grazing to meet aquatic, wildlife, watershed, and sensitive plant objectives. Bob Hughes, past president of the American Fisheries Society, provides a compelling overview of why livestock  The Fremont and Winema Forest Plans identify livestock grazing as a management tool to efficiently, effectively, and responsibly manage forage and non-forested plant communities on NFS lands (USDA Forest Service 1989, pp. 49–50; USDA Forest Service 1990, p. 4-12). This analysis was used to determine if livestock management practices are sufficient for achieving and maintaining compliance with current Forest Plan direction, applicable laws, and regulations. The effects are discussed in section 3.6 (fisheries), section 3.3 (wildlife), section 3.5 (hydrology), and section 3.2.1.3 (sensitive plants) of the EIS. Effects from climate change are discussed in section 3.10 of the EIS.  grazing is poor policy on public lands, especially the riparian management areas that dominate 90% of the forage base of the Antelope Grazing Allotments. Hughes 2014 p.388-389 states: “Riparian areas cover less than 2% of the West. However, livestock tend to aggregate in riparian zones, which are essential habitats for many terrestrial wildlife taxa and produce crucial aquatic habitat for fish [and Oregon spotted frogs] through their effects on channel morphology, food webs, water quality, and fish cover (Gregory et al. 1991; Baxter et al. 2005; Beschta et al. 2013). Those livestock aggregations remove riparian vegetation, trample stream banks, initiate incision or widening depending on channel slope and substrate, reduce groundwater and stream flow, elevate water temperature, increase turbidity and sedimentation, and lead to eutrophication (Platts 1991; Beschta et al. 2013).”  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  “Climate change projections indicate that western rangelands will become even drier and subject to more extreme flood, drought, and fire events. Livestock grazing exacerbates climate change effects on stream, riparian, and upland natural resources. Greatly reducing public land livestock grazing would greatly reduce this spatially extensive pressure and thereby reduce the susceptibility of those resources to climate change.” “Many of the damaging effects of grazing can be reduced by markedly decreasing the number of animals grazed, greatly limiting their access to riparian zones, and fallowing large areas for multiple years (Knudson 1999). Although there are certainly many conservation-minded ranchers, it makes little sense to me to subsidize livestock grazing on public lands for three major reasons.”  RN10  We assert the DEIS is defective because it lacks a 21st century science based approach to managing riparian lands in the project area. Hughes 2014 makes a compelling case that livestock grazing can no longer be credibly promoted on these riparian dominated allotments by stating “ [the] best available science identify livestock grazing as a management tool to efficiently, effectively, and responsibly manage forage and non-forested plant communities on NFS lands.”  Riparian effects associated with grazing have been disclosed in section 3.1.2 of the DEIS as well as in the hydrology specialist report.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  RN11  The alleged “science” supporting grazing as a “management tool” in riparian management areas needs to be fully examined as an issue (i.e. scoping).  The issues developed as a result of scoping are detailed in section 1.7 of the DEIS. This project had two scoping periods (11/01/2010 and 09/26/2011) because the Forest felt there was enough change between the original proposed action and the modified that it would be appropriate to scope again. Using the process for NEPA compliance, if an EA cannot determine whether effects are non-significant, or if effects are unknown, an EIS will be prepared. This would occur after the scoping period (FSH 1909.15_11.6, Exhibit 01, p. 19). A third scoping period was deemed unnecessary because the proposed action did not change again. Scoping was held early in the process, the proposed action was presented, and issues were identified and used to create alternatives. Comments received during the comment period did not present any concerns different than those presented during the September 2011 scoping period.  RN12  The DEIS fails to adequately examine scientific controversy about using livestock grazing as a “management tool” in riparian management areas as compared with the science based benefits from livestock exclusion as documented in numerous publications and field observations over the past 20 years.  The Fremont and Winema Forest Plans identify livestock grazing as a management tool to efficiently, effectively, and responsibly manage forage and non-forested plant communities on NFS lands (USDA Forest Service 1989, pp. 49–50; USDA Forest Service 1990, p. 4-12). This analysis was used to determine if livestock management practices are sufficient for achieving and maintaining compliance with current Forest Plan direction, applicable laws, and regulations.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  RN13  2. The Notice of Intent FR 79:65923-24 failed to “Describe the agency's proposed scoping process including whether, when, and where any scoping meeting will be held.” CFR 40: 1508.22 Notice of intent. ``Notice of intent'' means a notice that an environmental impact statement will be prepared and considered. The notice shall briefly: (a) Describe the proposed action and possible alternatives. (b) Describe the agency's proposed scoping process including whether, when, and where any scoping meeting will be held.(c) State the name and address of a person within the agency who can answer questions about the proposed action and the environmental impact statement. CFR 40: 1501(g) Using the scoping process, not only to identify significant environmental issues deserving of study, but also to deemphasize insignificant issues, narrowing the scope of the environmental impact statement process accordingly ( 1501.7).  This project had two scoping periods (11/01/2010 and 09/26/2011) because the Forest felt there was enough change between the original proposed action and the modified that it would be appropriate to scope again. Using the process for NEPA compliance, if an EA cannot determine whether effects are non-significant, or if effects are unknown, an EIS will be prepared. This would occur after the scoping period (FSH 1909.15_11.6, Exhibit 01, p. 19). A third scoping period was deemed unnecessary because the proposed action did not change again. Scoping was held early in the process, the proposed action was presented, and issues were identified and used to create alternatives. Comments received during the comment period did not present any concerns  CFR 40: 1505(d) Using the scoping process for an early identification of what are and what are not the real issues ( 1501.7)  different than those presented during the September 2011 scoping period.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The Notice of Intent (NOI) for this impact statement does not “describe the agency's proposed scoping process including whether, when, and where any scoping meeting will be held”. The NOI does reference a scoping period from 11/2010 for a 2012 EA that was withdrawn in 2013. At the very end of the NOI, six “preliminary issues” are identified. We assert that the NOI should have identified a “proposed scoping process” to obtain up to date information regarding the identification of significant environmental issues. There has been no scoping period for this project since September 2011. Since 2011 federally listed wolves are now known to visit the area. Grazing in wolf habitat is an obvious issue missing from the 2010/2011 scoping. The Oregon spotted frog was listed and critical habitat identified. Grazing in federally identified critical habitat is an issue missing from the 2010/2011 scoping since it was only fully identified in 2014. Chronic and damaging trespass grazing was reported in 2012, 2013 and 2014. Trespass grazing/lack of effective herd control is an issue missing from the 2010/2011 scoping. Severe drought occurred during 2013-2014 and many scientists expect drought to be a recurring phenomenon over the next ten years. Drought is an issue missing from the 2010/2011 scoping since it had not occurred. Alleged “science” that supports using livestock as a “management” tool in riparian areas no longer exists or is outweighed by numerous new studies of riparian areas. (i.e. scientific controversy). We do not believe that commenting on this DEIS can substitute for the missing and legally required scoping process. The lack of a timely scoping process will cast doubt on the credibility of this DEIS which is based on scoping information that is 3 years old for a 2012 EA that has been withdrawn.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  RN 3. The EA fails to provide a reasonable range of alternatives. a. None of the EA alternatives adequately address the need for recovery actions to restore sensitive/threatened species habitat and recover species (e.g. Oregon spotted frog) to viable numbers in the unique Jack Creek/Walker Rim ecosystems. This alternative would recover the Jack Creek Oregon spotted frog population, restore and protect fens and associated species, permanently exclude grazing within existing fenced meadows, restore Round Meadow, maintain existing allotment boundaries, and complete Oregon spotted frog restoration projects.” This 2014/2015 DEIS process erred by not including a restoration alternative as previously suggested by the public during 2010/2011.  RN18  First, the Fremont Winema National Forest cannot describe a “purpose and need” so narrow that only the proposed actions developed by the Forest Service meet the “purpose and need” thus providing the self-serving rationale to reject the restoration alternative.  The purpose and need for action are described in section 1.2 of the DEIS. FSH 2209.13 Chapter 90 sections 92.21 thru 92.32a discusses the scope of the analysis and purpose and need. “The purpose and need statement should simply explain why the action is being proposed.  The purpose and need statement should answer the questions:  “Why here?” and “Why now?”” FSH 2209.13 Chapter 90, Sect 92.22  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The need is based on the project at hand; answering the questions of why here, why now. The Forest Service is directed to comply with the Rescission Act of 1995 to complete NEPA analyses for grazing allotments per a schedule of completion. The analysis is to determine whether grazing should be reauthorized or not and if so, to what management level. One of the need statements is “where consistent with other multiple use goals and objectives, meet Congressional intent to allow grazing on suitable lands…” (EA, p. 1-3). Analysis included other multiple use goals and objectives such as plants, soil, and water when determining the effects of grazing.  RN19  Second, circumstances have changed. The Oregon spotted frog is a federally listed species and the Forest has a duty to make listed species recovery a top priority for all land management decisions.  The effects disclosure for Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1) was updated in the DEIS to reflect its change in status.  RN20  Third, there is a plethora of new information about habitat needs of Oregon spotted frogs and new information and new inventory techniques for managing Groundwater Dependent Ecosystems (i.e. fens) that could be integrated into a restoration alternative. For example, it is now believed that a viable Oregon spotted frog population needs a minimum of ten acres of open water habitat. None of the alternatives address the amount of open water habitat needed by Jack Creek Oregon spotted frogs.  A No Action Alternative that eliminated grazing was included in the range of alternatives as described in section 2.3.1 of the DEIS. In addition, the Jack Creek site management plan is the guiding document for Oregon spotted frog recover efforts.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  RN21  Fourth, as described in item 1 above, this DEIS process failed to engage the public in formal scoping process where the public could collaborate with the Forest to develop a non-controversial and science based restoration oriented alternative. The public involvement process including scoping has entailed the following public scoping/comments and public meeting activities: Public Scoping occurred on 11/2010, 09/2011, public comment periods occurred on 12/2013, 10/20112, the project has been listed in the quarterly SOPA since 5/2010 and there have been public meeting on: 10/23/2012, 02/22/2013, 03/05/2013, 07/06/2013 and 07/06/2013 for this project. We object to alternatives 2, 3 and 5 and the Jack Creek Spotted Frog Site Management Plan because they failed to consider accomplishing resource objectives by reducing cattle numbers and reducing grazing duration rather than increasing the area grazed and increasing grazing duration.
