The DEIS has not taken a hard look at impacts to Oregon spotted frogs. The DEIS has not adequately considered all direct, indirect, and cumulative impacts to Oregon spotted frogs. The DEIS p. 3-74 identifies 9 parameters important to the survival of Oregon spotted frogs that would be degraded or made worse with alternatives 3&5. Nevertheless, the DEIS fails to take a hard look at what habitat degradation and direct mortality from grazing means to the long term viability of Oregon spotted frogs on Jack Creek. For example, the DEIS fails to make an objective estimate of the probability of OSF surviving in Jack Creek over the next ten years with each alternative. The DEIS seems to imply there are no real OSF population consequences from alternatives 3 and 5 grazing while claiming that no grazing in alternatives 1 and 4 would have “both negative and positive impacts”. The DEIS cumulative effects table 312 (p. 3-79) is contradicted by Table 3-11 (3-74). There is no scientific reason why damaging grazing from alternatives 3 and 5 (Table 3-11) would disappear and miraculously cause improvement with cumulative effects analysis. The DEIS fails to adequately describe trespass (aka unauthorized grazing) in the context of cumulative effects. Any benefits from reduced grazing use on private lands with alternatives 3 and 5 would be offset by adverse impacts from trespass grazing. The DEIS ambivalence and conflicting assessments leaves the public and the decision maker with no clear differences in the choices among the alternatives because the DEIS has no clearly stated consequences to OSF with alternatives 3 and 5 grazing.  Impacts to Oregon spotted frog are detailed in section 3.3.1. The effects determination for the proposed action was “may impact individuals or habitat, but will not likely contribute to a trend towards federal listing or cause a loss of viability to the population or species”. Additional detail is included in the wildlife biological assessment/biological evaluation.  RN25  The DEIS (p. 3-74;Table 3-11) fails to identify inherent conflicts between beaver and livestock. This is an obvious and important indirect impact to OSF because cattle compete with beaver for food. Cattle presence is known to discourage beaver colonization. OSF need beaver dams to increase open water habitat.  Lack of beaver presence was a threat to Oregon spotted frog that is analyzed in section 3.3.1.1.2 of the DEIS.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS lacks baseline data about frog distribution, adult densities, metamorph densities, juvenile densities, open water habitat acres, and quality of open water habitat. It appears that only egg mass data has been collected and analyzed since 2007.  Page 20 of the wildlife technical report states, “Due to the lack of adequate surveys for all frog life stages throughout the Jack Creek system, all identified OSF habitat will be considered occupied for this analysis.” The lack of data was included in the assumptions for the wildlife effects analysis.  5. We object to reintroduction of grazing to the North Sheep pasture because it will have significant impacts to newly detected spotted frogs. This pasture is still recovering from previous grazing that exceeded Forest Plan Standards for land allocation Riparian Management 8. Recent expensive erosion control measures in this pasture will be put at risk with renewed grazing. Grazing will be concentrated in land allocation Riparian Management 8. Proposed grazing will retard further recovery and contribute towards a downward trend. Trespass grazing is common in this pasture and needs to be stopped before authorizing new grazing. Ongoing trespass grazing may already be causing downward trend or exceedance of Forest Plan standards. One of 3 forage monitoring sites (Bull Frog) remains in poor condition (DEIS 3-11).  The effects analysis for wildlife included 261 acres of Oregon spotted frog habitat in the North Sheep Pasture (Table 3-9 in the DEIS). Livestock grazing is not being “reintroduced” to these areas. These lands are current managed under an active grazing permit that authorizes 2 herds at 419 cow/calf pairs per month, with permitted grazing from May 15 to September 30.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  6. We object to Round Meadow not being identified in the DEIS as potential Oregon spotted frog habitat and managed for future frog introduction (Photos 5,6). a. Round Meadow is currently fenced and excluded from livestock grazing within the Chemult pasture of the Antelope Allotment. Oregon spotted frog introduction would provide a high need and priority for full wetland restoration.  The DEIS (page 3-75) acknowledges that Round Meadow may or may not provide the habitat variables necessary for all life stages of Oregon spotted frog, including suitable overwintering habitat. It continues that the likelihood of discovering OSFs at Round Meadow is low, and relocation would likely be the only potential for establishing a population at Round Meadow. Therefore, Round Meadow was not considered  b. There are no predatory fish or bullfrogs in Round Meadow. Similar habitats (Big Marsh) have abundant and viable Oregon spotted frog populations. Minor amounts of Reed canary grass can be controlled. c. Round Meadow is “representative” of the historical geographical and ecological distributions of OSF. d. Round Meadow would contribute needed resiliency for OSF viability because of its large size and stability. e. Round Meadow would contribute needed redundancy for the Jack Creek OSF population that is at precariously low abundance. The DEIS:3-71 states that maintaining [spotted frog] habitat would also allow for reintroduction if the [Jack Creek] population becomes extinct in the near term. A spotted frog population at Round Meadow would provide a source population if the Jack Creek population is extirpated. f. Round Meadow is suitable for introduction and would provide OSF viability in the future should stochastic events extirpate the nearby extant Jack Creek population.  potential habitat for Oregon spotted frog in this assessment.  7. We object to the DEIS because it fails to disclose that Jack Creek spotted frogs are likely to be extirpated during the next ten years regardless of alternative chosen.  The EIS uses best available science and Appendix D describes adaptive management and monitoring process, including thresholds for action.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS p. 3-71 states that maintaining [spotted frog] habitat would also allow for reintroduction if the population becomes extinct in the near term. Speculation about reintroduction gives the reader and decision maker the false impression that extirpation of Jack Creek spotted frogs is easily reversed. The loss of this unique high elevation population would be an irretrievable loss and constitutes a significant but undisclosed impact. The DEIS 3-78 erroneously states that “The impacts to habitat will be unmeasurable at the scale of the Forest. Therefore, this project will not contribute to a negative trend in OSF viability on the Forest.” The cumulative effect of livestock grazing over space and time over the last 20 years has certainly contributed to the potential loss of this isolated population of spotted frogs. The loss of any frog population would certainly contribute to a negative trend as discussed in the Oregon spotted frog listing. There are no surplus OSF populations on the Fremont-Winema Forest that can be lost.  8. The DEIS has not taken a hard look at impacts to fens. The DEIS has not adequately considered all direct, indirect, and cumulative impacts to fens and associated sensitive species.  Effects to fens are discussed in section 3.5 and effects to sensitive species are discussed in section 3.2 of the DEIS.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS fails to acknowledge that some fen area or fen function has been destroyed by grazing and permanently lost. The DEIS inventory techniques only inventory the larger fens while ignoring smaller fens and ones that have lost fen function. This is important because unique fen habitat is extremely rare east of the Cascades. The DEIS takes the cavalier attitude that since there are a lot of fens in the project area, it’s acceptable to degrade many with cattle grazing. The DEIS fails to acknowledge that some fens, especially those in poor condition, already have lost or will lose desired wetland function unique to fens due to cattle grazing. The devastating effects of compaction and herbivory from grazing are belittled as a temporary effect because cattle forage grows back every year. The obvious resource conflict with fens being used as late season watering areas for cattle is ignored and obfuscated. The use of a degradation standard (i.e. 10% bare ground) as a “goal” demonstrates a profound lack of concern for ecological integrity with respect to wetland impacts. Purposely grazing a sensitive wetland to 10% bare ground is a serious impact that has been passed off as “meeting” Forest Plan standards.  9. The DEIS is defective because it fails to acknowledge that the gray wolf is present, has been present recently, or will be present in the project area during the next ten years. Grazing is likely to have adverse impacts to wolves currently establishing breeding populations in southern Oregon as they have in NE Oregon.  “Wolves are habitat generalist species…” “While their habitat is present there are no wolves known to be present in the Antelope Allotments Grazing project area. In addition, this project will not affect the species or modify its habitat. Therefore, this species will not be carried forward in the analysis (Wildlife report page 25)  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS p. 3-67 (Table 3-8) indicates that wolf habitat is present but no wolves are present. The Table falsely indicates that wolves would not be affected by proposed grazing. An addendum to the Yamsi Grazing Allotment Wildlife Report Dated July 7, 2014 states that “Due to the recent discovery of gray wolf activity on the Fremont-Winema National Forest, there is the need to document any potential effects to this species. Wolves are considered a federally endangered species on the Fremont-Winema National Forest.” Gray wolves west of Hwys 395-78-95 in Oregon remain protected by the federal ESA and a radio collared wolf has been known to pass through areas in the vicinity of the project area. http://www.dfw.state.or.us/wolves/ Recently a wolf has been documented of having fed on but not killed livestock near Fort Klamath. Another wolf has been captured on camera in Klamath County near Keno. Wolves have home ranges that cover hundreds of square miles. The DEIS cannot assert that wolves will not be present in the project area over the next ten years.  The presence of elk in the project area also means the allotment must be considered habitat for predatory wolves. NEPA requires the agency to take a hard look at the impacts to ESA protected gray wolves. NEPA requires compliance with other laws, including the ESA. The DEIS fails in both regards. The DEIS fails to disclose how the various alternatives complies with the ESA listed gray wolf. The DEIS fails to disclosure of how the alternatives will or will not cause take of the gray wolf. The DEIS fails to report what level of consultation occurred with the US Fish and Wildlife or ODFW about gray wolves. The DEIS fails to disclose that a wolf pack has established on nearby Rogue River Siskiyou National Forest and that there is near certainty that wolves will frequent the project area during the next ten years and beyond. The DEIS fails to identify expected wolf-livestock interactions as an issue for analysis.  “Wolves are habitat generalist species…” “While their habitat is present there are no wolves known to be present in the Antelope Allotments Grazing project area. In addition, this project will not affect the species or modify its habitat. Therefore, this species will not be carried forward in the analysis (Wildlife report page 25)  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS is defective because it does not address the likely use of the allotment by wolf packs sometime in the next 10-20 years. The DEIS fails to include any acknowledgement of anticipated wolf/livestock interactions and possible harm to wolves should wolves interact with livestock. The DEIS failed to consider measures to reduce potential livestock/wolf interactions. For example, 2015 AOI instructions to remove dead livestock so they are not scavenged by wolves. This standard precaution is already being implemented by Rogue River-Siskiyou N.F. The DEIS failed to consider eliminating calf grazing on the allotment that would greatly reduce potential for wolf depredations. Wolves rarely predate on adult cows, however, cattle mired in fens would be easy prey for wolves (Wildlife Technical Report p.52). The Monitoring Plan has nothing about monitoring wolf activity (cameras) or identifying corrective actions should wolves occupy the allotment and interact with livestock (i.e. adaptive management decision triggers). The DEIS failed to acknowledge that livestock create conflicts with elk, a favored wolf food species.  “Wolves are habitat generalist species…” “While their habitat is present there are no wolves known to be present in the Antelope Allotments Grazing project area. In addition, this project will not affect the species or modify its habitat. Therefore, this species will not be carried forward in the analysis.” (Wildlife report page 25) Wolf management is under the guidance of the State of Oregon and not the Forest Service, the Forest Service does not manage wildlife populations that is the job of the state.  The Fremont-Winema National Forest has taken measures to directly inform the livestock grazing permittees on the west side of the forest about the presences of wolves and the potential need for changes in future management and has communicated this information to permittees on the east side of the forest as well. If changes in management are needed in the future they will be addressed on a case by case basis. Monitoring of wildlife population is an Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife activity, the Forest Service participates cooperative in various monitoring activities within the administrative boundaries of the Fremont-Winema National Forest. The effects to elk from livestock grazing have been disclosed in the wildlife report on pages 154-157 and pages 164-167.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The agency has failed to satisfy its duties under NEPA with regard to the gray wolf.  The effects analysis for gray wolf was not included in the DEIS because the species is not present in the project area (Table 3.8 of the DEIS). .“Wolves are habitat generalist species…” “While their habitat is present there are no wolves known to be present in the Antelope Allotments Grazing project area. In addition, this project will not affect the species or modify its habitat. Therefore, this species will not be carried forward in the analysis.” (Wildlife report page 25)  10. We object to the DEIS because it fails to adequately disclose that cattle will become mired and die in fens which can contribute substantially to pollution of the aquifer.  Comment noted.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Cattle loss is an irreversible and potentially significant impact that cannot be mitigated with adaptive management. The Wildlife Technical Report p.52 states “[t]here have been a couple incidents of cattle getting stuck and dying in this area [upper Jack OSF habitat]. Besides the pollution effect, the economic loss of whole cow may not justify the pounds gained from cattle foraging in fens. Due to this unique risk of mortality to cattle in fens, many fens are never “range ready” and it is not responsible grazing management to allow this risk to occur annually.  13. The DEIS fails to disclose that cumulative impacts from a century of livestock grazing are not easily reversible with mere exclusion of livestock. Restoration will require costly intervention. (See Comment Letter #1, item 29, p. 40)  Cumulative impacts from historical grazing was disclosed for each resource in Chapter 3 of the DEIS and within each of the specialist reports.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  14. The DEIS assertions that ecologic conditions will improve with reintroduction of grazing into exclosures and pastures (not currently grazed) are not scientifically credible. The proposed alternatives 3 and 5 will allow grazing to damage up to 10% bare ground in these sensitive areas contrary to Forest Plan S&G 23. Adaptive management appears to only address impacts in excess of this standard, but long term ecological damage is likely to have occurred long before the 10% Forest Standard is exceeded. Grass may grow back in trampled areas but that does not mean that gullies from trailing or streambank trampling has not contributed to further reduced wetland function (Photos 3,6-12). The DEIS failed to disclose that resumed grazing in areas currently excluded from grazing is certain to have adverse impacts that will be allowed to accumulate until exclusion is once again necessary. The DEIS fails to acknowledge that adaptive management strategy to allow grazing until the impacts exceed some standard is not a credible restoration technique. Ecological impacts are not easily reversed with short periods of rest as with deferred grazing. Gullies, headcutting, stream channel widening, aggradation, loss of surface flow and lowered water tables are long term and possibly irreversible impacts. Source installed on adjacent private land. The permittee for this pasture has grazed their private lands where Oregon spotted frogs are known to occur, although the number of cattle and timing are not known. However, the permittee has also partnered with the Service to complete multiple conservation actions to benefit Oregon spotted frogs and their habitats on their private lands including—but not limited to—the installation of 2 to 3 offsite watering sources, protection of frog ponds, thinning of encroaching lodgepole pine trees, and installation of a wattle for water retention (Markus 2012, pers. comm.).  There is a difference between soil damage and detrimental soil conditions that the 10% applies to. Due to the speedy recovery after a season of use occurs and cover is returned this is not likely to trend in exceeding desired condition over time. As stated in section 3.7.2.4.1, using additional grazing lands, coupled with a shortened grazing season, deferred rotation strategy, and utilization of riparian units, would distribute the cattle across a broader landscape. Additionally, opening the six fenced riparian units (Dry Meadow, Squirrel Camp, Rider’s Camp, Cannon Well, Jack Creek Riparian Unit, and Round Meadow) to grazing would help alleviate soil resource impacts within the riparian areas of concern. The riparian areas of concern would continue to be impacted by cattle grazing. Although soil compaction, post-holing, pedestalling, and trampling would continue to occur, adverse impacts would be less than under current management. To ensure Forest Plan standards are met, soil monitoring would be conducted in these riparian areas, in addition to resource protection fences being constructed at some locations.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Conflicts between cattle and frogs increase when stream flows are limited, especially when cattle are using the creek for drinking (Gervais 2011, p. 15). Between 2001 and 2005, and again in 2007, drought conditions affected habitat for Oregon spotted frogs in the Chemult Ranger District, Fremont-Winema National Forest in Oregon. However, until 2008, when grazing was restricted, 419 cow/calf pairs had access to the habitat areas associated with Oregon spotted frogs (Gervais 2011, p. 11). Cattle were observed congregating in Oregon spotted frog habitat because nearly every other water source in the allotment went dry (Simpson 2002, pers. comm.). Trampling of frogs by cattle and alterations in water quality, bank structure, and loss of protective vegetation compounded the impacts of the reduction of available habitat due to drought conditions on Oregon spotted frog reproduction (USDA 2009a, pp. 31, 33–34).”  Direct trampling was analyzed as one of the threats to Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1.1.2 of the DEIS). The effects disclosed in this section in the DEIS state, “Research indicates that High Intensity/Low Frequency (HI/LF) grazing systems can change the spatial distribution of grazing and cause animals to graze the landscape more uniformly by decreasing the time of exposure to grazing and trampling.”  Livestock Grazing Conclusion—Whre livestock grazing coincides with Oregon spotted frog habitat, impacts to the species include trampling of frogs and changes in habitat quality due to increased sedimentation, increased water temperatures, water management techniques, and reduced water quality. The effects of livestock grazing vary with site conditions, livestock numbers, and timing and intensity of grazing. In Washington, all of the known occupied areas have been grazed in the recent past, but where grazing has been removed, heavy infestations by invasive reed canary grass have reduced or eliminated habitat for Oregon spotted frogs unless other management techniques were applied. In controlled circumstances, moderate grazing can be beneficial if it is the only practical method for controlling invasive, nonnative vegetation and sustaining short vegetation characteristics needed for egg laying. Grazing is ongoing in 10 of the occupied sub-basins and is considered to be a threat to Oregon spotted frogs at these locations.” (emphasis added)  The effects of grazing to Oregon spotted frog were analyzed in section 3.3.1 of the DEIS. Alternatives 3 and 5 had a “may impact individuals or habitat, but will not likely contribute to a trend towards federal listing or cause a loss of viability to the population or species” effects determination for Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1.2.4 of the DEIS.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  We assert that based on analysis in the listing and site conditions at Jack Creek there is no credible scientific reason to claim a benefit to Oregon spotted frogs with the grazing scheme in Alt. 5 because grazing can only harm Oregon spotted frogs and their habitat in Jack Creek. There are no concentrations of reed canary grass that need removal by livestock as occurs in Washington. The principal limiting factor for OSF in Jack Creek appears to be annual loss of summer rearing habitat (i.e. open water) due to low summer flows in Jack Creek and lack of off channel pond habitat or in channel pool habitat (e.g. beaver dam pools).  Alternative 5 had a “may impact individuals or habitat, but will not likely contribute to a trend towards federal listing or cause a loss of viability to the population or species” effects determination for Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1.2.4 of the DEIS).  Furthermore, we object to the use of the Oregon Spotted Frog Site Management Plan (dated November 28, 2011 and cited as Gervais 2011) as a basis for grazing Oregon spotted frog habitat with alternatives 3 and 5. (See DEIS p. 2-12). New information in the listing of Oregon spotted frogs and new information about short period (trespass) grazing during 2013 and 2014 indicate that this grazing strategy is not appropriate as a conservation measure for Jack Creek Oregon spotted frogs. Grazing suggested in the SMP would cause considerable harm (DEIS p. 3-74) and likely contribute to the extirpation of the Jack Creek population. Appendix B in the SMP must be updated with the removal of proposed short duration grazing in Oregon spotted frog habitat.  There are a number of actions and non-actions that would be beneficial to spotted frogs. The Jack Creek Oregon Spotted Frog Site Management Plan is one tool that holistically looks at the habitat in Jack Creek and provides a framework for improving habitat and species recovery which includes grazing and the impacts from grazing. There have been and continues to be decisions and supporting analysis for accomplishing many of the listed actions in the Site Management Plan. Just because this analysis has focused its review on whether to continue grazing does not mean other actions are not occurring or being considered.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  We object to the Forest Service failure to request US Fish and Wildlife Service assistance with development/updating of the SMP and the failure of the DEIS to include expert opinion from the US Fish and Wildlife Service. For example, the DEIS p. 3-80 falsely states that “The incremental effects of Alternatives 3 and 5 to OSF and OSF habitat, when added to all of the past, present and reasonably foreseeable future actions are not expected to impact the viability of OSF populations.” The DEIS provides no scientific basis for this conclusion which is contradicted by the best available science in the Oregon spotted frog listing.  The scoping document was sent to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS). The Forest Service has completed a Biological Assessment and is in consultation with the USFWS on a Biological Opinion regarding the project for OSF.  17. Winema Forest Plan page 4-47 item number 4-6 states: “Forest personnel shall not identify (to the public) specific location information that could jeopardize the welfare of an endangered, threatened, proposed or sensitive species.”  Therefore maps showing only general locations of proposed habitat are displayed in the project file.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  “New information we received from the U.S. Geological Survey indicated that the proposed critical habitat unit did not include the full extent of occupancy by Oregon spotted frogs along Jack Creek (C. Pearl, USGS, pers. comm. 2014). Therefore, we propose to include an additional 180 acres (73 ha) in this unit. Upon consideration of the information we received, this refinement includes approximately 3.1 miles (5 km) of Jack Creek and its adjacent seasonally wetted areas south of U.S. Forest Service Road 88 through 1.32 mi (2.12 km) of O'Connor Meadow. The additional acreage is occupied by the Oregon spotted frog and contains the physical or biological features essential to the conservation of the species. Eighty-two acres (33 ha) are managed by the Fremont-Winema National Forest, and 98 acres (40 ha) are privately owned. The essential features within the additional acres may require special management considerations or protection to ensure maintenance or improvement of the existing nonbreeding, breeding, rearing, and overwintering habitat; aquatic movement corridors; or refugia habitat, and to address any changes that could affect these features. The total acreage of proposed critical habitat in Unit 12, after this refinement, is 15,332 acres (6,205 ha) in Klamath County, Oregon.”  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS:3-72 quantifies acres of Oregon spotted frog habitat in various pastures but does not map or quantify officially proposed critical habitat. This is important because “[t]he regulatory mechanism through which critical habitat protections are realized is section 7 of the Act, which requires Federal agencies, in consultation with the Service, to ensure that any action authorized, funded, or carried out by the agency is not likely to adversely modify critical habitat. Therefore, under these circumstances only Federal action agencies are directly subject to the specific regulatory requirement (avoiding destruction and adverse modification) imposed by critical habitat designation. Under these circumstances, it is our position that only Federal action agencies will be directly regulated by this designation.” (79FR34690)  The Forest Service has completed a Biological Assessment and is in consultation with the USFWS on a Biological Opinion regarding the project for OSF. Winema Forest Plan page 4-47 item number 4-6 states: “Forest personnel shall not identify (to the public) specific location information that could jeopardize the welfare of an endangered, threatened, proposed or sensitive species.”  Therefore maps showing only general locations of proposed habitat are displayed in the project file.  First the DEIS must accurately quantify and map proposed critical habitat. The Wildlife Technical Report p.51 states that “OSF habitat on USFS and private land were identified based on the designation of critical habitat for the species as well as the criteria that the USFWS used to delineate critical habitat based on 2012 aerial photo imagery and mapping all associated riparian and wetland habitats.” However, there are no maps provided in project files or DEIS that illustrate the precise location of habitat analyzed. Thus, we cannot determine that proposed critical habitat was indeed analyzed for impacts. For example, maps of OSF habitat in the Site Management Plan are erroneous and unclear.  The Forest Service has completed a Biological Assessment and is in consultation with the USFWS on a Biological Opinion regarding the project for OSF. Winema Forest Plan page 4-47 item number 4-6 states: “Forest personnel shall not identify (to the public) specific location information that could jeopardize the welfare of an endangered, threatened, proposed or sensitive species.”  Therefore maps showing only general locations of proposed habitat are displayed in the project file.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Second, impacts to proposed critical habitat must be analyzed in this EIS/decision process. The most important component of critical habitat likely to be impacted by grazing is open water habitat during the low flow summer period. Neither the DEIS nor the Wildlife Technical Report has quantified or inventoried OSF open water habitat during the low flow summer period. This is important because research indicates that a viable Oregon spotted frog population requires about ten acres of open water habitat. Currently Jack Creek falls far below that minimum standard.  The acres of Oregon spotted frog habitat permitted for grazing on National Forest System lands was a measurement indicator for comparing effects to Oregon spotted frog (Table 3-10 of the DEIS). In addition, loss and alteration of wetland habitats and succession toward woody vegetation were analyzed as threats to Oregon spotted frog (Table 3-11 of the DEIS).  Third, impacts to critical habitat must be based on the best available science which is summarized in the proposed listing. Assertions that grazing has benefits to Oregon spotted frogs at Jack Creek has no credible scientific basis because there has been no documented need for habitat alteration (e.g. more open areas for oviposition). The assertions of benefits for OSF from grazing at Jack Creek (Wildlife Tech. Rept. p.78-79) are speculative and biased  Positive influences on vegetative resources by controlled grazing is discussed on page 3-81 of the DEIS.  18. Alternative 3 and 5 will degrade (make worse) 366 acres of Oregon spotted frog critical habitat. Alternatives 3 and 5 will graze 366 of 377 OSF critical habitat acres (97%), but only protect 11 acres (3%) (DEIS Table 3-10; p3-73). Alternatives 3 and 5 will reduce 9 habitat parameters for OSF (DEIS Table 3-11; p. 3-74; “Reduce = the function of an indicator changed to a worse rating compared to the environmental baseline;”) This is stark admission that grazing in alternatives 3 and 5 will be harmful to Oregon spotted frogs and the harm disclosed is consistent with the best available science information about grazing in the OSF listing (USFWS 2014a).  These effects are disclosed ins section 3.3.1 of the DEIS.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS p.3-75 y states that “[r]emoving livestock grazing from Jack Creek will remove the potential to maintain an early seral vegetation structure or remove biomass from oviposition sites (White 2002). In addition, moderate, controlled grazing can be beneficial if it is the only practical method for controlling invasive, nonnative vegetation and sustaining short vegetation characteristics (early seral habitat) needed for egg laying (FR 78, No. 162, p. 51675).” There has been no data presented that oviposition sites along Jack Creek would benefit from grazing. There is no need to control invasive nonnative vegetation on Jack Creek. This DEIS citation to the78 FR are out of context. The following discussion from (USFWS 2014a) explains why Jack Creek is not likely to benefit from grazing. The final listing for Oregon spotted frog (USFWS 2014a:5176) states “Cattle grazing ceased at Trout Lake NAP in Washington after a monitoring study showed no apparent positive effect on the Oregon spotted frog population trends (Wilderman and Hallock 2004, p. 10), indicating either that grazing was not an effective tool for reed canary grass management at this location, or that perhaps reed canary grass was not as threatening to breeding frogs at this location as previously thought. This may be because winter snow pack flattens the reed canary grass, creating a mostly sun exposed water surface available to Oregon spotted frogs during the breeding season. The observed negative consequences of grazing, while perhaps acceptable if there was clear benefit to the Oregon spotted frog populations, were not compatible with other site management goals and posed a limitation to future restoration on the site (Wilderman and Hallock 2004, p.14).”  Positive influences on vegetative resources by controlled grazing is discussed on page 3-81 of the DEIS. A No Action Alternative is analyzed according to section 2.3.1 of the DEIS.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Similarly, snowpack flattens grass at Jack Creek making grazing unnecessary for oviposition habitat. Heavy infestations of invasive non-native grasses do not exist on Jack Creek and where reed canary is found it is being treated with herbicides making grazing unnecessary. Assertions in the Wildlife Technical Report and DEIS of benefits to Oregon spotted frogs from livestock grazing at Jack Creek are specious and unwarranted (i.e. they do not apply for OSF habitat at Jack Creek).  Positive influences on vegetative resources by controlled grazing is discussed on page 3-81 of the DEIS. A No Action Alternative is analyzed according to section 2.3.1 of the DEIS.  The reduced winter snow pack over the past two winters would indicate that relying solely on snowpack to effectively flatten vegetation is not necessarily a reliable or effective method to obtain desired open water conditions.  19. The Wildlife Technical Report fails to provide the required Biological Evaluation for the Gray Wolf. Conservation measures to reduce deleterious wolf-livestock interactions have not been identified. Formal consultation is required for Oregon spotted frogs, not informal consultation resulting in a “Letter of Concurrence”. Under ESA § 7(a)(2), a federal agency must “insure that any action authorized, funded or carried out by such agency … is not likely to jeopardize the continued existence” of any listed species or adversely modify its habitat. 16 U.S.C. § 1536(a)(2). If a proposed action “may affect” a listed species or its critical habitat, the action agency must consult with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS). Id. at § 1536(a)(2); 50 C.F.R. § 402.14(a). To fulfill its Section 7(a)(2) mandate, the action agency prepares a biological assessment (BA) to evaluate potential effects and determine whether the action is likely to adversely affect a listed species. 50 C.F.R. § 402.12.  .“Wolves are habitat generalist species…” “While their habitat is present there are no wolves known to be present in the Antelope Allotments Grazing project area. In addition, this project will not affect the species or modify its habitat. Therefore, this species will not be carried forward in the analysis.” (Wildlife report page 25) The Forest Service has completed a Biological Assessment and is in consultation with the USFWS on a Biological Opinion regarding the project for OSF.  If the proposed action is likely to adversely affect a listed species, the action agency must seek “formal” consultation with FWS. 50 C.F.R. § 402.14(a). Formal consultation results in issuance of a biological opinion (BO) by FWS. The BO determines whether the proposed action is likely to jeopardize the continued existence of a listed species or adversely modify its critical habitat.  The determination was made that the project “may impact individuals or habitat, but will not likely contribute to a trend towards federal listing or cause a loss of viability to the population or species” for Oregon spotted frog, not that it would likely adversely affect a species.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The Forest Service has completed a Biological Assessment and is in consultation with the USFWS on a Biological Opinion regarding the project for OSF.  If the proposed action is not likely to adversely affect a listed species, the action agency may seek “informal” consultation with FWS. 50 C.F.R. § 402.14(b). Informal consultation concludes with a Letter of Concurrence from FWS, and is only appropriate when the BA or other information indicates that the action has no likelihood of adverse effect to the listed species. Here, the Fremont-Winema National Forest has failed to consult with FWS in violation of § 7(a)(2) because its actions “may affect” gray wolves or Oregon spotted frogs. When an action agency’s proposed action may affect listed species, it must prepare a BA and consult with FWS over its determinations in the BA. The Forest has neglected to do this.  The Forest Service has completed a Biological Assessment and is in consultation with the USFWS on a Biological Opinion regarding the project for OSF.  In its July 2014 Wildlife Addendum for the Yamsi EA, the Forest  Gray wolf was determined to not be present in the  acknowledges that it needs to consider the effects on gray wolves  project area (Table 3-8 of the DEIS).  from its proposed approval of grazing on Yamsi allotment because  the species and/or habitat is present on the allotment or “it is probable that individual wolves may disperse through the project area” during the life of the 10-year permit. The project area provides deer, elk, and other prey species year-round. Similar conditions exist for Antelope project area.  “Wolves are habitat generalist species…” “While their habitat is present there are no wolves known to be present in the Antelope Allotments Grazing project area. In addition, this project will not affect the species or modify its habitat. Therefore, this species will not be carried forward in the analysis.” (Wildlife report page 25)  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  “The minimum threshold for an agency action to trigger consultation is low.” Western Watersheds Project v. Kraayenbrink, 632 F.3d 472, 496 (9th Cir. 2010). To determine whether [an agency’s] no effect determination was arbitrary and capricious, we must decide whether [it] ‘considered the relevant factors and articulated a rational connection between the facts found and the choice made.’ A federal agency ‘must initiate formal consultation if its proposed action ‘may affect’ listed species or critical habitat; and ‘any possible effect, whether beneficial, benign, adverse, or of an undetermined character, triggers the formal consultation requirement.’ The [agency’s] decision to forgo consultation with FWS must be reversed if the [agency] ‘entirely failed to consider an important aspect of the problem’ or offered an explanation that runs counter to the evidence before the agency.’ Id. (internal citations omitted).  The Forest Service has completed a Biological Assessment and is in consultation with the USFWS on a Biological Opinion regarding the project for OSF.  The Wildlife Technical Report p. 25 states “While their habitat is present there are no wolves known to be present in the Antelope Allotments Grazing project area. In addition, this project will not affect the species or modify its habitat. Therefore, this species will not be carried forward in the analysis.” This erroneous statement is contradicted by an Addendum to the Yamsi Grazing Allotment Wildlife Report Dated July 7, 2014 which states that “Due to the recent discovery of gray wolf activity on the Fremont-Winema National Forest, there is the need to document any potential effects to this species. Wolves are considered a federally endangered species on the Fremont-Winema National Forest.”  Comment noted.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  A wolf pack has established on adjacent Rogue River Siskiyou  .“Wolves are habitat generalist species…” “While  National Forest. The Biological Evaluation (BE) for OSF contained in the wildlife technical report is inadequate/defective because the Forest Service failed to conduct an up to date survey for Oregon spotted frogs on Jack Creek and failed to inventory the suitability and acres of open water habitat for OSF. No survey of spotted frog habitat and presence has been made recently to support impact assessment. The only field data reported in the BE is egg mass numbers data through 2014, which is important, but certainly not sufficient for assessing grazing impacts to the federally listed Jack Creek spotted frog population. For example, the BE has no field data about the (pasture) specific location or densities of OSF adults, juveniles, or metamorphose in various reaches of Jack Creek. Baseline data to assess or monitor impacts is lacking. This is a serious monitoring omission for an easily monitored frog species that is known to be threatened with extinction. Similarly, the BE has no recent data about the quality or quantity or quality of aquatic habitat for OSF. The 2002 stream survey was designed for fish not frogs. The data from this stream survey cannot be used for 2014 BE impact analysis because its 12 years old. It is not the best available scientific information since a more recent survey could have been completed prior to issuing the DEIS.  21. The Biological Evaluation for OSF (wildlife technical report) and the EA are misleading, biased, and plain wrong because they fail to accurately describe the significant degradation of OSF habitat from chronic trespass (aka unauthorized) grazing which appears to have resulted in direct trampling mortality of at a least one OSF during 2013.  Direct trampling was analyzed as one of the threats to Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1.1.2 of the DEIS). The effects disclosed in this section in the DEIS state, “Research indicates that High Intensity/Low Frequency (HI/LF) grazing systems can change the spatial distribution of grazing and cause animals to graze the landscape more uniformly by decreasing the time of exposure to grazing and trampling.”  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The Wildlife Technical Report p. 81 states that “There is a potential for unauthorized use or unauthorized cattle use to occur within the allotment and its associated pastures. In the event this use occurs the effects would be similar to the effects of authorized grazing. However, the FS has permit violation policies in place to deal with this occurrence (USDA 2005, p. 29). In addition, there are monitoring and compliance personnel directly associated with this allotment, therefore while the effects will be similar they will be greatly reduced and managed in a timely manner.”  The DEIS falsely states that “A potential for unauthorized use to occur within the allotment and its associated pastures exists. However, as described above, this potential would be minimal and the effects would be negligible.” The speculation about the negligible effects of unauthorized grazing in the wildlife technical report and DEIS are demonstrated to be false by actual field observations reported by T. Simpson, J. Goodwin, and Forest Service staff emails. Terry Simpson reported the following in an email dated July 29, 2013 to Fremont-Winema Forest staff: “I encountered 4 herds of Iverson cattle along this section of the creek. Cattle signs are everywhere. They are tearing up the pools and walking on top of frogs getting a drink.”  Comment Noted.  The unauthorized use issue has been addressed through the appropriate administrative actions.  This section of Jack Creek is not in the existing allotment and the cattle were not authorized to be there. We have previously documented numerous incidents of severe and chronic trespass grazing for the 2013 EA and have again submitted this factual information for this DEIS record (see attached letter #1 item #3 Trespass Grazing) .  Comment noted. The unauthorized use issue has been addressed through the appropriate administrative actions.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Terry Simpson also documented an apparent OSF trampling mortality from trespass grazing. We find it disingenuous for the wildlife technical report and the EA to dismiss a known serious and chronic impact to a federally listed species as “negligible”.  Direct trampling was analyzed as one of the threats to Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1.1.2 of the DEIS). The effects disclosed in this section in the DEIS state, “Research indicates that High Intensity/Low Frequency (HI/LF) grazing systems can change the spatial distribution of grazing and cause animals to graze the landscape more uniformly by decreasing the time of exposure to grazing and trampling.”  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response   There is no direct evidence that the mortality of one or any frogs has been caused by livestock.  The photograph is speculative at best as to what may have caused the death of the individual frog in the photograph.  Direct trampling was analyzed as one of the threats to Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1.1.2 of the DEIS). The effects disclosed in this section in the DEIS state, “Research indicates that High Intensity/Low Frequency (HI/LF) grazing systems can change the spatial distribution of grazing and cause animals to graze the landscape more uniformly by decreasing the time of exposure to grazing and trampling.”  Short duration trespass cattle grazing in Jack Creek Oregon spotted frog habitat caused severe trampling damage and likely degradation of water quality due to cattle urination in small stagnant pools used by Oregon spotted frogs (photo at right). One frog mortality was documented in a hoof print (left photo) and many others likely perished when cattle and frogs competed for water in small pools. Frog photo by Terry Simpson on 5 Oct 2013 and trampling damage photo on 1 September 2013.  22. The DEIS cannot rely solely on Oregon spotted frog habitat acres as a surrogate for population change, population viability or numeric index for impact analysis because the relationship between habitat acres and spotted frog numbers or viability is not defined in the DEIS.  Population surveys have been conducted since 1998 at various locations throughout Jack Creek. The wild life report page 55 summarizes the survey that have been conducted  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS 3-71 states that “[t]he Jack Creek OSF population is at critically low numbers, with fewer than 20 known breeding females. Because such small populations are prone to wide fluctuations solely due to chance, frog numbers are not a reliable benchmark for management actions. Instead, habitat characteristics can serve as restoration goals and triggers for changes in management strategy.” While habitat is certainly important for impact analysis, the DEIS cannot forgo likely quantitative impacts to the frog population when the DEIS does not provide quantitative relationships between frog numbers and acres of habitat (especially sites with quality open water habitat). The DEIS has no systematic scientific inventory of frog habitat, inventory method to classify habitat into condition classes or a method to identify presence of critical features within reaches or pastures. The scientific baseline for OSF habitat and abundance is inadequate to assess impacts.  .The determination was made that the project “may impact individuals or habitat, but will not likely contribute to a trend towards federal listing or cause a loss of viability to the population or species” for Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1.2.4).  23. Contrary to what is stated in the DEIS, Alternatives 3 and 5 will substantially contribute to the loss of Oregon spotted frog viability on the Fremont-Winema National Forest. The DEIS is not ensuring that the grazing will be consistent with the Forest Plan because the Forest Service is not managing for viable populations of frogs across the Forest The DEIS p. 3-78 states: “This project impacts a very small portion of suitable habitat across the Forest, and the overall direct, indirect, and cumulative effects will result in small-scale negative impacts to habitat, as well as some positive impacts to habitat. The impacts to habitat will be unmeasurable at the scale of the Forest. Therefore, this project will not contribute to a negative trend in OSF viability on the Forest.”  The determination was made that the project “may impact individuals or habitat, but will not likely contribute to a trend towards federal listing or cause a loss of viability to the population or species” for Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1.2.4).  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  This analysis is flawed because it fails to recognize the significance of the Jack Creek population of Oregon spotted frogs and the deleterious impact of Alternatives 3 and 5 on that population. The Jack Creek Oregon spotted frog population is one of only 4 extant populations on the Fremont-Winema National Forest. The US FWS 2014a reports that due to lack of monitoring population trends cannot be determined on for the Sevenmile, Fourmile and Williamson populations. The Jack Creek and Buck Lake populations have declined drastically. Thus the Fremont-Winema National Forest has failed to demonstrate viability of any Oregon spotted frog populations on the Forest, either individually or as a collective whole. Since each Oregon spotted frog population on the Forest is separated from other “source” populations by several miles, each must be considered as individually needed to maintain viability in the Forest as a whole.  The effects to OSF are discussed within the EIA pages 3-68 to 3-80 and extensively within the Wildlife report on pages 19-20, and from page 42116. The determination was made that the project “may impact individuals or habitat, but will not likely contribute to a trend towards federal listing or cause a loss of viability to the population or species” for Oregon spotted frog (section 3.3.1.2.4).  The Forest Plan says to maintain viable populations of species across  The determination was made that the project “may  the forest. Rept pp.84-88). Proposed degradation (“reduced”) of 9 OSF habitat parameters on 97% of the OSF’s habitat on Jack Creek can hardly be deemed “negligible”. Because of its location, the Jack Creek population contributes substantially to providing OSF distribution across the Forest. The loss of the Jack Creek population would contribute to the loss of viability of Oregon spotted frogs on the Fremont-Winema National Forest and the species as a whole.  Section 3.3.1.1 analyzes the direct and indirect effects of the alternatives on Oregon spotted frog.  While habitat is important for impact assessment, habitat cannot be used as surrogate for actual OSF numbers and populations because the relationship of habitat and OSF numbers is unknown (see #4 above). The Fremont-Winema National Forest has failed to adequately monitor all of its Oregon spotted frog populations. None are believed to be viable (USFWS 2014a) and the Jack Creek population has declined precipitously.  Population surveys have been conducted since 1998 at various locations throughout Jack Creek. The wild life report page 55 summarizes the survey that have been conducted  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEISp.3-80 falsely states that “Alternative 5 may impact individuals or habitat, but will not likely contribute to a trend towards federal listing or cause a loss of viability to the population or species”. This is certainly true for the Jack Creek population that may be less than 50 individuals. The DEIS failed to identify protection and mitigation requirements provided by USDI Fish and Wildlife Service. The Winema Forest Plan (p. 4-47) states: “If endangered, threatened, or proposed species are found in a project area, consultation requirements with the USDI Fish and Wildlife Service shall be met in accordance with the Endangered Species Act (Public Law 93-205). Before a project can be carried out, protection or mitigation requirements shall be specified (NFMA, 36 CFR 219.27[a][8]).” (emphasis added)  As noted in section 1.8.6 of the DEIS, the Forest Service is in consultation with the USFWS The Forest Service has completed a Biological Assessment and is in consultation with the USFWS on a Biological Opinion regarding the project for OSF. Any requirements made by the USFWS will be included in the Record of Decision and will be incorporated into the Allotment Management Plan and related grazing permit.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The Winema Forest Plan.4-67 S&G 9-19 states: “Allotment management planning, an interdisciplinary process, shall provide for cost-effective management of range vegetation consistent with land stewardship practices Planning shall involve grazing permittees, other range users, interested publics, and other agencies. As AMPs are written and updated, management emphasis shall be the intensification of vegetation management and forage utilization consistent with other resource objectives. The emphasis also shall be on cost-effectives administration.” The Forest Service purposely excluded the USDI Fish and Wildlife from AMP planning contrary to S&G 9-19 and despite interest by the Service to participate. (See Cmt letter #1 , item 6, p.15)  As noted in section 1.8.6 of the DEIS, the Forest Service is in consultation with the USFWS  The Forest Service has completed a Biological Assessment and is in consultation with the USFWS on a Biological Opinion regarding the project for OSF. Any requirements made by the USFWS will be included in the Record of Decision and into the Allotment Management plan and related grazing permit.   25. We object to Alternatives 3 and 5 because it fails to provide for: 1) adequate monitoring of sensitive species, 2) adequate monitoring and prevention of Riparian Management Area 8 degradation, 3) adequate integration with Jack Creek Site Management Plan, 4) specific course of action to reduce grazing intensity in fair and poor condition fens and 5) a schedule for improvement. We object to Implementation Monitoring in Fens (Appendix D-7) because it inappropriately allows for downward trend in fens as measured with percent “bare soil”. The wording of the Desired Future Condition is a grazing loophole to allow for grazing damage and downward trend in fens and riparian management areas contrary to the Forest Plan standard to “maintain or improve” these riparian areas. The DEIS fails to use the appropriate Allotment Management Planning Standard and Guideline 9-23 that was specifically written for riparian area management. (See comment letter #1, item 9, pages 25-26).  The proposed pre-turnout monitoring would address soil conditions within identified sensitive areas. The monitoring results would determine if and when grazing would occur within these areas.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  27. We object to the use of a single criteria (% bare ground) as  Page 7 of Appendix D explains, “Monitoring of  the principal threshold factor about the condition and trend of  bare soil in fens was chosen for the following  riparian areas and fens as they relate to annual operating and ten year  reasons. The Antelope Grazing Allotments  AMP decisions concerning livestock grazing distribution (Appendix  Environmental Impact Statement identified soil  D and Botany Report). (See comment letter #1, item10 p. 26.  impacts as a primary concern for livestock grazing in fens in the project area. Disturbance to soft peat soils from livestock trampling may reach levels of concern in fens before Forest Plan vegetation utilization standards are met. Although factors, such as depth of peat, depth to the ground water table, and dominance by peat-forming plants are important in maintaining fen condition, these factors are less likely than soil disturbance to be indicative of the current season use, and are not useful measures for annual implementation monitoring. Livestock trampling disturbance in fens creates bare soil and compaction in the form of hoof prints, trails, and pedestals. Some of these impacts may persist for several years, but monitoring and observation of fens in the project area indicate that fairly rapid regrowth of vegetation and reduction of bare soil can occur during ungrazed periods. Measuring bare soil is, therefore, a good indicator of annual grazing use:  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  Also, as noted on page 42 of the botanical technical report, “As described in Appendix B, monitoring and adaptive management would be used to ensure all 8 fens ranked as high value for sensitive plants are maintained in good condition or trend toward good condition during the 10 year timeframe of the analysis. An assumption is made that habitat for sensitive fen species would be best maintained in the project area by maintaining proper functioning condition as defined by Weixelman and Cooper (2009) in the high value fens.” Appendix B of the botanical report notes that the 8 highest value fen habitats in the project area would be monitored, including a presence/absence assessment of sensitive species. In addition, soil monitoring would occur annually and be the primary measure used to determine fen condition and vegetation would be resampled every 5 years to determine if any species shifts have occurred (p. 135 of the botanical technical report).  28. We object to proposed grazing in the Chemult Pasture with alternatives 2, 3 and 5. The Chemult Pasture is currently not suitable for proposed intensive cattle grazing because it is in need of extensive restoration to prevent sensitive and listed species loss. Adaptive management based on permissive 1990 Forest Plan standards is not likely to restore severe degradation caused in part by decades of livestock grazing.  All of the proposed grazing systems (section 2.3 of the DEIS) on the Chemult Pasture are new and developed to spend less time in an area, provide greater dispersal of cattle and associate utilization. This is to be contrasted with the season long grazing currently being used. Lengthened time between grazing, changing the timing of grazing, should allow better recovery for season ending desired conditions.  No.  Comment  Forest Service Response  The DEIS p.1-7 states that 90% of the forage in the allotment is within riparian areas (Management Area 8) and that percent is even higher in the Chemult pasture where cattle use is concentrated along streams and in wet meadows/fens. Six fens are in poor condition due to livestock grazing and seven others in fair condition. The DEIS asserts that Forest Plan standards allow for 10% bare ground in riparian areas where pedestalling and compaction would be severe, however, these 13 fens currently exceed Forest Plan standards as reported in Botany Report (Table A3). Headcutting associated with loss of beaver and loss of aspen is degrading Jack Creek (Photo Attach. Photos 7-13). Spotted frogs are nearly extirpated and Miller Lake lamprey trend/abundance is unreported.  29. The proposed spotted frog listing indicates a minimum of ten acres of wetland is needed for a viable spotted frog population. (See Comment Letter #1 , item 12, p. 27-29)  Section 2.3.8.2 of the DEIS fully describes the implementation monitoring proposed for this project and Appendix D describes the adaptive management strategy.  30.
